content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												I am in love with Primordia! I found this game randomly and I am soo glad I did! Beautiful environment/sprites, engaging story, and classic point-and-click gameplay done right. This game is truly a work of art! I think this game gets the point-and-click puzzle/adventure aspect right in a way that many of these types of games fall short - the puzzle solving logic is straight forward and makes sense. You won't get left scratching your head, unable to move forward because of a vague goal or illogical item use to solve puzzles. Very enjoyable to play through and though I haven't finished the game just yet I can see the replay value being high considering there are multiple endings.BONUS - The Primordia world is enhanced through the game's website: http://www.primordiagame.com/A prequel story: http://www.primordiagame.com/fallen_complete.pdfAnd an audiobook version can be listened to here: https://www.youtube.com/user/WormwoodStudiosInc/videosI honestly don't have anything bad to say about this game. I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys post-apocalyptic or dystopian tales set in a futuristic/sci-fi world with themes focusing on Robots, and retro style point-and-click puzzle games where story is the highlight of the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												Primordia is a point and click adventure game set in a post-apocalyptic world strewn with pieces of machinery.  You play as Horatio Nullbuild, who has a rather peaceful existence ruined when a powerful robot steals the power source of his ship.  Horatio and his companion Crispin leave their home and head for the city of glass and light - Metropol.  Here, you will uncover secrets of your past and gain a better understanding of humans who previously walked there.Primordia does not reinvent the genre, it is a sci fi adventure game that offers a dark and meaningful story - something lost in some modern point and click games.  The game provides excellent atmosphere, a rich script, solid puzzles and an art style that is really captivating.  It is the sort of game that tries to restore the classic point and click genre and I believe it has truly nailed it.  It feels like the 90's, but shows that with careful animations, voice acting and intricate details, that 'modern' resolutions and graphics are not always necessary.I wanted to find out more and had to see the different endings, take different paths and look for more information online.  The only fault would be that it is perhaps too short, especially if you are used to classic adventure games.  Some puzzles were pretty difficult and there were a few moments of "That doesn't make much sense", though that's something I always expect from these games.It is not really going to interest people who don't play point and click games.  It is for people who miss games like The Dig, Beneath a Steel Sky and maybe even the classic Fallout games (in terms of atmosphere).  It has replay value, great soundtrack, top storytelling and is certainly difficult enough to stump you in a few places.  Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												The first thing you will probably notice about Primordia is that it is a beautiful game. The graphics are pixellated, but not in the sense often used by amateur indie designers as an obvious cost-cutting measure. This is pixel art at its finest: lovingly crafted details in every background and most characters show that the game's artist took their work extremely seriously. That effort paid off in spades.The second thing you will probably notice about Primordia is that almost everything about it is bleak. This is not the post-apocalyptic world of Fallout, where things have gone to hell but black comedy keeps things from getting too dark. There is humor in the game, but it works in spite of the world being broken, not because of it. Humanity is extinct, its robotic creations and their creations in turn forming what qualifies for society in Primordia's shattered world. Energy is life, and power is running out.The third thing you will notice is that often the game works in a far more logical way than others in its genre might lead you to expect. Early on you see a lantern on a high shelf your character cannot reach. The solution? Ask your hovering robot sidekick to push it down. There are a lot of moments like that in Primordia, where logic prevails over the typical adventure game "must be as drunk as the original designer to comprehend" school of puzzles. That said, there are still moments where you may not figure out on your own. I had to look things up at least a couple times in my playthrough to advance. Not everyone will, and I would discourage players from reading up except as a last resort. The puzzles make up a huge chunk of the game. If they are not your thing, I would say the game is still worth playing with a guide for the atmosphere alone.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												After a total 11 hours of playing, I've finished Primordia. As a point-and-click the gameplay is mainly based on puzzles and some basic crafting, but its steampunk atmosphere, its hughely charismatic characters and its deep and thought-provoking messages are the strongest part in the game.In general, Primordia creates a powerful discourse about justice, law, charity, industry and energy, community and knowledge, energy and history. Most importantly, about logic and free will. As a player, you are brought to wander in an environment that is partially an echo of men's life, partially an odd representation of robotic life, where to the decay of humanity is counterposed the need for energy of the last city on earth. Every knowledge is lost in the dust, and Metropol, the city where the two protagonists will find themselves in, is a ghost city whose only side still provided with energy is a long road. I will be haunted by its finale for a while, also because of its powerful credit OST. It leaves its scars, but worth, worth playing.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												For those who grew up on the point and click adventure games of old (Monkey Island, Full Throttle, et cetera), they aren't dead - you just need to know where to look. To those who haven't, point and clicks are largely narrative-driven games based upon exploration and puzzles - and this game has all three in spades. Intriuging setting? Done. Tough, but (almost always) fair, puzzles? Done. A compelling narrative? Oh yeah. This game has all of two downsides - first, that clues are sprinkled into the dialogue, but there isn't a way to reexamine or replay it, so sometimes you're left guessing. Second, the game is short - but this is more of a nitpick than anything, because its actual length belies the completeness which the game concludes with. Ultimately, this is a great work by a talented team, and the only real reason you wouldn't like it is because you don't like point and click adventures.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												This game has an excellent story and a unique and interesting setting filled with charmingly colorful characters.  It is thoughtful and meaningful, and addresses some serious theological and philosophical points, while remaining mysterious and exciting (most of the time).  However, I found the gameplay to be very lacking, in a number of ways.  I'm now going to complain about all the things I need to complain about, but do please recall that I actually enjoyed this game :)The puzzles in this game were difficult, and not in a good way.  While many of them had "cool" solutions - which would be awesome in a movie, for example - they were often not cleanly solvable, in the sense that they were the only plausible solution and made everything "make sense" when you figured it out.  For me, a lot of the reason I want to play a puzzle game is for that awesome feeling of everything coming together when I figure it out.  This is not the sort of game that does that for me.  Here's a few of the problems that I saw:1. Trying to create a clever solution rather than a good puzzle.  The solutions to puzzles are often the sort of zany solutions that are fun to watch heroes think of in movies, but not reasonable to force the player to think of.  In other words, they don't feel like THE solution, just A solution (and yet in the confines of the game, they are THE solution).2. Tooooo many items.  Unlike a lot of games, in Primordia you almost never get an item taken out of your inventory when you are done using it.  By the end of the game, I have so much stuff in my inventory that the task of getting through a locked door has dozens of reasonable-sounding solutions - crowbar, plasma torch, signal transmitter to pick the lock, etc, etc - but only one of them is right (and it's probably none of the standard things I've learned how to do throughout the game, because that would be to easy).3. Generic, reusable items.  This is one of my pet peeves in puzzle games.  When you have a generic item like a hammer, there's a trillion and five ways that the player can think of to use this item.  Even if the game designer could think of all of those, allowing those solutions would make many of their puzzles too easy.  Anyway, this game is full of generic items that you use again and again throughout the game (but are never allowed to use when you think of it).4. Confusing items.  I had a whole bunch of electronic gadgets and doodads that it took me a long time to figure out how they worked - a signal transmitter, a decryption device, a memory reader, etc.  All of these could be used only in very specific circumstances (i.e. as far as I can tell, the memory reader can only be used to access memories from a severed robot head - which you encounter in this game a lot more than you would think!), but this information is never explicitly told to you (I never really figured out what the rules for the decryption device were).5. Just too much going on at once.  The game is basically divided into two parts.  During each part, you slowly unlock more areas, and then can travel freely between all areas that you have unlocked during that part, which by the end of each part results in a huge environment in which to look for a small number of remains tasks.The end result of all of this was that I played the game with a walkthrough constantly ready.  And I do not regret it :)  Most of the things I had to get help on ("most" because I started getting lazy near the end), I think I would have felt frustrated rather than satisfied if I took the time to solve myself.The interface is unfathomably archaic and unintuitive.  For example, the process of using an item - one of the most base necessities of a point and click game - requires (1) hovering near the top of the screen to open the tool bar, (2) selecting the inventory button to open your inventory, (3) selecting the item from the inventory, (4) clicking outside the inventory to close it, then finally (5) clicking on the thing in the world that you want to use the item on.  On all the interfaces mentioned, there are also many confusing and sometimes unnecessary/duplicate buttons.  The datachron (which automatically takes notes on things you have learned) has a horrific interface that looks something like an old school gameboy, with giant text on a tiny screen, and buttons (that you have to click with your mouse) for scolling up and down.  Similarly, the signal transmitter - on which you frequently need to set a 4-digit number to transmit - is pretty obnoxious, requiring you to click on the left and right sides of two dials (not even buttons that you can see, so it's hard to find the sweet spot to actually click on) - one to cycle through numbers, and one to cycle through DIGITS.  DIGITS.All that being said, however, I think this game is definitely worth playing for the story alone, which like I said is fantastic.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												Primorida is one of those games that's really emotionally devastating and depressing and you do feel bad for the characters and the world, but there's also that part of you that didn't really attach yourself to the characters and you're almost kinda glad to have it over and done with.As a point-and-click adventure game (and as a story) its all really well put together. The graphics and music create an eerie setting. Upon entering the city of Metropol, I immediately felt a disease with everything around me. Every step taken is a direct threat to the big bad, for the mere fact you aren't obeying her every word from the get-go. The knowledge that the bad guy is watching your every move and is intelligent enough to start planning hundreds of steps ahead makes me shiver.The puzzles are what you'd expect in a robot apocolypse: very technological, a strict sense of rules behind each one. All give off an extra feeling that speaks to me as "yep. Puzzles caused by robots alright."By the end though, I didn't feel particularly emotionally affected. Which was weird because I did feel for the characters. I gasped at plot twists, I shivered at the Big Bad, and my heart felt like it was stepped on when spoiler stuff happened. But I suppose it was just brief moments of emotions rather than a lasting impact. Maybe apocolypse stuff isn't my thing. Maybe it was that the darkness of the plot sort of negated any victory. I won but it didn't feel like a win. Maybe that was the point.Whatever, I'm rambling. TL:DR: its a good game. Really. If you play point-and-clicks or apocolypse games are your thing, check it out.

												This game has some of the most intelligent writing and spot-on voice acting out of anything I've ever played. That kept me trucking through more than anything else. The humor in particular is well done, and perfectly timed. I actually thought the art and graphical design was interesting, and didn't mind the "crudeness" of the animation, etc. If anything I felt like it added to the atmosphere and feel. The puzzles are well thought out, but can get maddeningly difficult if you forget to scribble down key information that isn't recorded by your logger at some points. I also enjoyed all the hidden homages tossed in that aren't thrown in your face. The ending seemed to come too quickly, but I was only disappointed that there wasn't more to do.I only wish that it was easier to adjust the scaling other than having to edit a file. Before doing that, it's often difficult to spot clues and changes in the environment. The music can get a bit repetitive as well.Other than that, this is a developer to keep an eye on if you're into this genre.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												Point-and-click adventure games were one of the first things I ever played: When I got my first computer around 1994-’95 I played Discworld with my dad. We had a walkthrough since neither of us could understand English. Since then I have gone mostly to other genres but the adventuring spark were left in me somewhere. That’s why I have bought a great many point-and-click games but every time I play one the same thing happens: I click around for a while and get bored. They just don’t get a grip on me. That was until Primordia.The player takes role of Horatio and his sidekick Crispin, who live in a post-apocalyptic wasteland. What seems like a peaceful existence is interrupted when a robot crashes through their wall and steals a power core that is keeping the two alive. The game is a quest to find and get back the power core. The mood is melancholic and sad but is lighten up by Crispin’s surprisingly funny dialog. Every other character was also fascinating and had some personality to them.This was the first ever adventure game that I completed without looking at a walkthrough. Most of the puzzles are logical in a sense that if you have an item that might fit it most likely does. Every solution made sense. The puzzles are quite varied: There are use-item-on-item puzzles but also drawing, memorization, code breaking and so on. I was surprised at how many different kind of obstacles the creators had thought out. It took 7 hours to complete the game, though length varies greatly depending on how fast you solve the puzzles. There appears to be different endings and outcomes since I only got half of the achievements on single playthrough.The graphics in this are amazing. Everything is a post-apocalyptic bleak wasteland but the world that was destroyed has this art deco kind of style (think Bioshock) that is really nice. The game actually runs at the tiniest of resolutions but is stretched to full screen. Not a lot of pixels to work with but what has been achieved is wonderful. I’d love to see full resolution images of the art since it’s so great. This is also why the game probably runs on pretty much any potato as long as there is electricity. For some strange reason in one room, after certain thing happens, my fps dropped to single digits but it was solved after I got out of the room. You cannot die and there is no rush so it doesn’t matter. Even better than the visuals is the sound and music. I think the voice acting is great but, together with the art, it’s the music that shines the most. If you have any interest in point-and-click Primordia is a must play, no doubt about that. For someone new to the genre it’s also a good place to start since it’s not as far-out weird with its puzzles as some games in the genre. I can only give a big recommend for this wonderful game!

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												Primordia is a cyberpunk game about faith. Much like in the movie Tron, the main character is a robot with a mission he forgot. A mission given by his own creator, Man.Primordia is a point-and-click adventure game by Wormwood Studios. The main character is a robot with amnesia, but made for a very significant purpose. It is still his choice to fulfill this purpose. He can be a faithful warrior that defeats the evil progressive mind and unites the robots, or he can run away from it. In the game, the robots live under a totalitarian secularist regime, where the belief that the machines were created by a mysterious being called Man is forbidden. His faith in Man keeps the protagonist alive. It is a very interesting twist for the cyberpunk genre.The graphics are beautiful, as well as the soundtrack. The voice acting is complete and very well done. The voice of Crispin is the best. The dialogues are funny and the developers opted for a more dynamic gameplay, allowing the player to engage in the story without huge dialogues.One of the advantages is a map that saves the player a good time that would be wasted wandering around. Another advantage is the "automatic notes", which saves you the trouble of writing down important information. There are several ways to solve the puzzles, and the developers sought to avoid puzzles that are incoherent with the setting. There is a great internal system for tips, preventing players from getting stuck.If you like games like Beneath a Steel Sky, or games that allow you to immerse in an engaging and deep atmosphere with unique and intriguing stories, you should give a chance to Primordia.Positive points* Amazing setting.* Good writing and voice-acting.Negative points* The engine is limited.

												I hardly recommend this game to anybody new to the genre. While the game offers multiple solutions to their puzzles, the most important ones are quite complicated for the casual player. It offers a handy hint system to keep progress (Sometimes a bit too vague however) but you'll find inmense difficult spikes in some parts of the game.If you can handle the challenge the game is a very solid adventure from beginning to end. Starts with a simple premise and snowballs the plot through the end. It also offers multiple endings so you can experiment with alternative solutions and choices in consequent playthroughs. The graphics and artstyle offers wonderful atmosphere and character design, but I advise you to play it windowed since the sprites don't transition well in full screen.Overall a must have for the fans of this kind of games, specially veterans which want tough puzzles but not a single or convoluted solution to solve them. It might force you to find a guide sometimes, but even so the story is great enough to experience by its own merits.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												Let me just start this review by giving you the following context: I very rarely play point-and-clicks. The most notable ones (namely, those by LucasArts) were before my time, so my only games in this genre I’ve played are the new Sam and Max games and this one.This genre greatly focuses on its writing and story, and I feel Primorida does well in that regard. What starts as a simple story of tracking a robot who stole your stuff turns into a one with many hints about the world and why it’s in the state it is, and Horatio’s role in it. Each character, from the straight-laced and practical main character Horatio, to his perpetually floating, snarky sidekick Crispin, and everyone else you interact with is written with enough skill to give them unique personalities without falling into two-dimensional archetypes. While many NPCs fall into some stereotypes of their characters (ex: a soldier robot speaks how you’d expect him to, likewise with a robot with a monocle), they get moments where they flesh out their character and have some very clever lines.The overall plot kept me guessing all the way to the end, but stayed mostly clear about what was going on the whole way through. The story is straightforward in that regard, although the littering of hints of the details behind the game world really helped the story shine when it revealed big plot elements.However, I NEED to talk about the gameplay. It’s your typical adventure game fare of solving puzzles by figuring out how items interact with each other, listening to context clues, etc. The game doesn’t go too crazy with the solutions.That being said, I will be honest and say I had to use a walkthrough for this game. This is most likely due to my inexperience with the genre, but many times I felt clueless on what to do. Furthermore, when I looked up the solution, I felt like the game gave me little to no inclination that what I was supposed to do may be the answer.PUZZLE SPOILERSOne of the most “how was I supposed to do that” moments was when I needed to figure out how to remove rust from gears so I could open a door. I hadn’t met anyone who was a cleaning robot or the like, and I had no items on me that implied they could clean. It turns out that in one segment, there are underwater “submersible” robots who, when I dunked the gears underwater where they were, cleaned the gears. When I clicked on them normally, the main character said NOTHING about their potential cleaning ability.Another annoying one was a moment of “I didn’t know I could do that”. I had to inspect a door in order to solve a puzzle, but left-clicking it gave me a quote that didn’t help me. However, right-clicking it gave me a different one relevant to the puzzle. I know that could right-click on items to hear a description of them in my inventory, but I didn’t know why I couldn’t just left-click this door to hear the contextually-important quote for this puzzle.END PUZZLE SPOILERSSo overall, I’d say that you should not feel ashamed if you need a walkthrough for certain puzzles in this game. The second half of this game has quite a few rather obtuse ones, which is a shame since they can halt the progression of what is otherwise a really cool story.My other problem is a technical one: this game has no resolution options! It can only either run in fullscreen (which I think is 1024x768!!!) or windowed which has a default size that is most suitable for ants. Thankfully you can turn the “scaling” up, which means increasing the size of the internal resolution (window size in windowed mode increases with this), but the lack of proper resolution options just strikes me as lazy to me.Lastly, and this is sort of a nitpick, but this isn’t Logan Cunningham’s best work. He does a decent job not sounding bored in his lines and emoting properly when necessary, but either due to sound engineering, low quality audio files, or otherwise not as much strength in his voice work, he isn’t as memorable as he was in Bastion. I felt the sidekick Crispin out-did him in passionately delivering his lines. It doesn’t detract from the game at all really, I’m more just feeling like he could have done better.SUMMARY:I strongly suggest you guys pick up Primorida. It’s got an interesting plot inside a unique atmosphere of a post-human world, and the writing does those both justice. The puzzles can be result in premature baldness due to hair-pulling difficulty, but they didn’t stop me from enjoying the game.

Posted: December 1, 2014
												Cool environment, interesting characters, good sci-fi/post-apocalypse story. Thoroughly enjoyed this point and click adventure. Some puzzles were quite confusing or non-sensical, but most are decent. I wish I could increase the resolution, but that seems to be a common thing with Wadjet Eye games. Overall it didn't detract too much from the experience. Occasionally the sidekick got annoying. Occasional crashes, once was catastrophic (had to restart from the beginning, thankfully I remembered everything), but usually stable. I'd recommend it if you like this sort of game and you can get it in a bundle or discounted.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												I do not like point and clicks.I love this point and click.Characters you actually care about. Very interesting story told mostly through implication rather than blatant exposition. At least as many allusions as any Fallout game. Despite the fact that the game is fairly small and your ability to explore and interact with the world are necessarily limited it still manages to create the impression of a much larger world. My only complaint, and it's a small one in this internet world, is that some of the bread crumbs are so far off the path that after you look up a walkthrough to get you unstuck you're left wondering how the first guy ever managed to figure it out in the first place.I have more money. If they ever add to this world I will have a little less.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Where can i start to review this game?On the surface it's an old shool point-and-click adventure, but the story, the voice acting, the art and the setting are simply amazing.Set in a post-apocalyptic world where machines have became sentient and capable of build (and re-build) themselves.In this world, humans are only a fading memory, kept in partially corrupted data gathered by some and spread in a form of a religion.Most of the world is now covered by the desert, where most of the androids live in a single huge city.This is the background where Horatio, the protagonist, starts its (his?) journey to find a stolen component of his ship, revealing part of his (and our) past in the process.The amazing art (all hand-made) and the attention to details of the world makes me heavily recomend this game to any point-and-click adventures fan with a soft spot for the post-apocaliptic setting :)

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												==New ReviewI've written a new review on completing the game. First I still think the warning applies: it should be made clearer that it runs 640x400.** That's not a full screen size image in the video**. However I found it best to turn on x4 anti-aliasing, this is the best option.This is a great story, nice main character and side kick, good voice acting, setting is interesting. I only got stuck a couple of times, and you know when you do in these games it's because you've missed something obvious or not so obvious on the screen. I'm not a fan of searching the screen for a clue and there is'nt  too much of that, but if you get stuck chances are it's that. The memorious puzzle was in fact a bit oblique to me, like I'd forgotten something in a trunk.I'd also say this is the type of game where even though the in game data collection works fine you will need a pen and paper for a couple of the code and logic puzzles but that's it. Mostly because getting it wrong the first time locks you out of achieving some of the achievements, though this does give you incentive to play again.  It has multiple endings so there's some replayability to it at the end. I'd compare the setting to Machinarium, but story style wise and feel more Beneth a steel sky. I happen to think those are two top games.To dev: I dont think a sequel would be possible *right now* but maybe a prequel  would fit really well here. Do a Star Wars and make a trilogy and jump around the timeline.Having read the Fallen pdf it did give me much more of a sense of story, I can see how things would be missing with out it. I'd put a link on the store page for download if it's not already there. Add the setting to right click change settings to the library entry.Top Rating=== old reviewI bought a bunch of point and clicks at the same time, and when I got this I really didnt realise it ran this size. It's too fiddly and post stamp size. I'm aware I can scale it up x4 but then it becomes quite hard to discern things in the picture, which is annoying.I don't have a problem with pixel art, and in some cases that's easier for finding things on screen rather than a high res style, but the art style here makes it too difficult to recognise things. I played through Techno Babylon no problem, which is at a larger resolution but something about that game has cleaner lines where as Primordia has a lot of detail. I'd compare this more to Machinarium style but pixelated.This could really benefit the clarity it has at 640x400 at a larger frame. I know that won't be possible without remaking it, but that might actually be worth doing...At the moment im in two minds about it and getting a refund.Which is a pity because im pretty sure it is good. Depends if you can live with that size. edit: use 4x anti-aliasing, it goes a bit dream like looking but it's certainly better. cheers===

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												A marvelous point'n'click adventure! Unique world design, great atmosphere and story, accompanied with nice music and a perfect voice acting. Its puzzles can be hard sometimes, but I think they're still easier to figure out than in older point'n'click games (e.g. Broken Sword or Flight of the Amazon Queen). I recommend it with whole heart!

Posted: July 19, 2013
												Golden age of point-and-click / text adventures might be gone, but this title brings you back to early 90's, when greatest classics were born. Primordia is pure 2D pixely adventure with unique art style, gripping story that will leave you thinking, great voiceacting (Logan Cunningham - Bastion) and atmosphere of dystopian future emanating from every single pixel. It should be noted that it shares couple of similarities with Beneath a Steel Sky, another great experience.Any fan of classic point-n-clickery can't go wrong with this one, as it is one of the best in its genre available on Steam. However it might be a little bit too short if you follow only the most straightforward path and forget to explore the backstory, explore details and solve few optional puzzles.

Posted: December 7, 2012
												I started this review thinking "i'd only reccommend this game if it was 10 dollars" then I saw the price and was like derp.Its another good point and click adventure game, it suffers from the faults of the genre simply because its part of the genre. That being said I loved the enviroments, the art direction in this game is really solid they capture the distopian depression look very nicely, and the world feels larger than the game itself. I found myself wanting to see more places more locations as the game drew to a close. Puzzles are still adventuregames issues, but, typically it involves how much you pay attention. This one likes to slap you with obvious solutions after you are predispositioned to go in an obtuse way.Overall, if you love adventure games and want a healthy dose of post human robotland distopia, you should get it.

Posted: July 28, 2013
												Superb point and click adventure. Interesting and beautiful world, the story is good and the puzzles are all logical and make sense. there are multiple ways to solve problems and several different endings. Certain puzzles/problems can be irreversibly failed, forcing you to find different solutions and in some cases altering the story/ending. If you like adventure games, buy it.

Posted: May 27, 2013
												A flawless game that leaves you hungry for more, this really is a magnificent indie game that oozes with a completely absorbing cyberpunk atmosphere. Great plot, great characters, often moving, the usual puzzling moments of point and click adventures that are executed very well, charming retro 90s-style adventure graphics, excellent overall design and a beautiful Vangelis-style soundtrack......This game is an absolute must for both fans of great point and dlick adventures and grim, atmospheric cyberpunk science fiction. I could happily play this over and over again and not get bored...

Posted: May 12, 2015
												What a great ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game.  So well done, so deep.  The only thing I felt lacking was the ending, but then I discovered that I had only experienced 2 possible endings out of SEVEN.  Top notch artwork.  Outstanding voice acting.  A gripping story in a world that could be our own.  I have never consumed ANY form of media that made me feel sympathy for a robot (except Marvin from Hitchhiker's, perhaps...)  I really can't wait for Wormwood Studios' next project.

Posted: June 5, 2015
												Ok so let me start off by saying even at full price this game is worth buying.It's goregous in a rusty-noir (that's mine) kind of way that, I honestly didn't think was possible with this type of rendering. This game has made me an instand wadjet eye fanboy.I experienced absolutely no bugs in my playthrough, I thoroughly enjoyed the voice acting, and the writing is excellent. I was able to play this game with my 3 year old in the room (you don't generally find such a dark story free of offensive language or innapropriate visual content so it's a huge plus for me.)Easily the best point and click game I have ever played (I've been gaming for 27 years now I like to think of myself as a connoisseur).If you like the point and click genre you NEED to play this.If you don't, but like a good story then I'd say you wont be dissapointed.You can read more about the story and setting in other reviews so I wont go into it. I'd just say that it was enthralling start to finish and the puzzles aren't brainwracking but you need to use your head throughout the game.

Posted: January 7, 2014
												A dark but not excessively dramatic game with a slight Planescape: Torment vibe to its atmosphere and side characters. The music is beautiful and well-chosen for the scenes that are meant to get to you (and they really do), and the voices feel spot on for most characters you meet. Some puzzles can get frustrating due to the combination of 'I don't need this right now' for interactable objects that you might or might not use in the future and objects that only become interactable when something else happens in a different area. However, dialogue usually contains hints on where you need to go, and your humorous floating skull sidekick might have something useful to say as well, so pay attention. There's a variety of endings, and you're not restricted to the path of the good guy, though, by that time you'll be questioning your definition of a 'good guy' and how good your actions actually were. This game will definitely make you think and not just about solving puzzles. tl;dr Buy it. It's great.

Posted: September 3, 2013
												If you love graphic adventures like I do, you cannot miss this game. Good story, great dialogues, humor, and a very interesting view on the science-faith debate. They could have done something better for what concerns the animations, but it definitely doesn't ruin the experience.Graphic adventure. Sci-fi. Humor. Interesting view on a controversial topic. Buy it.

												An awesome poethic game about life, death, and robots.And a fabulous story about Humanity, faith, justice and hope.A quest to return home with friends, to fly away having built a new world, a better one.Primordia is about what is primordial, and what is but Horatio and Crispin's Humanity ?Not flesh, but mind ? Not power, but friendship ?

Posted: June 22, 2015
												Fun old school point & click adventure. Definitely worth playing.

Posted: April 11, 2014
												Gemini Rue meets Machinarium. Great story, great voice acting from all except Crispin IMO. It's a point and click game with old style graphics, but the original and futuresque story makes up for it. The mood is brought to life with the scenery and music. I enjoyed searching for answers and learning about the world. Primordia and To The Moon are games you can talk about, have a life discussion about once they are over as they deal with deeper and hypothetical life scenerious.  I appreciate games that cane bring more to the table than kill bad guy, game over. My only complaints are some of the puzzles are really difficult to achieve without outside help (info kiosk words). I do not like using outside help, but one puzzle requires a typed guess, that's ridiculous.  The hardest achievement isn't impossible, but requires finding the right post in the forums (I just bumped it to the top recently for those struggling for 100%).  Even though there are multiple endings, they take place at the very end (obviously) so it's not like what you did earlier in the game  really mattered, unless you were trying to get the achievements.  Overall 8/10, I would have given it a 9/10 if that one puzzle was really impossible to figure out.

Posted: April 20, 2014
												A very strong adventure game in the mold of Day of the Tentacle or King's Quest. One of its features, missing from many other games of this genre, is a subtle hint mechanism to help when you are completely stuck. In the old days, this kind of "stuckness" was a death knell for a game that none of your friends had already beaten. Today, there's a different kind of problem, because you go all too easily to the internet to look up the answer. You do it begrudgingly, the first time, easier the second, and on the third time, you accidentally see how it ends.But back to the game in specific: a nice balance of humor and seriousness. I dig the universe the story is set in, which brings some pretty serious gravity to the plot, but you have a zany sidekick who really does actually grow on you. The writers did a great job making you care about the characters... who are robots... Addtionally, in stark contrast to many of the "Press a button to select your ending" problems some games have presented us with recently, there are something like ten seperate endings which are... all pretty different.  All in all, bravo, very fun game.

Posted: July 18, 2015
												A hidden gem on the Steam store, Primordia is a game that is about robots in a world where their creators have long since been gone. You are a robot named Horatio Nullbuilt with his best friend Crispin Harotiobuilt, and you two are living in a wasteland. This game is great at charather development and world building.Man is a god among robots and some say Man never existed. Some robots are barely surviving in the dying world they find themselves in. Others live together in Metro city, a strange place that seems like the last civil place on earth. When Horatio and Crispin's power core (the thing that keeps them alive and running) is stolen, they must embark on a journey using only stuff they can salvage in classic point and click style to find whats rightfully theirs. The gameplay is simple, but like most point and clicks it's about the world and the story is tells. And it tells a good story. Without wanting to spoil anything, trust me and get this.

Posted: June 21, 2015
												I absolutely adored this game. The story was compelling enough for me to feel invested without becoming so complicated that I lost interest. The visuals and sound track are stunning. The dialogue is well written. Crispin is a little talkative but I grew to enjoy his company. The puzzles have a range of difficulties. My only issue with the game was it crashed on my a few times. Posted: July 15, 2015
												I've always been a fan of the adventure games Myst and Riven. My favorite part about these games, as a kid, was that they whisked you away to a completely different, and foreign place. Though many adventure games seek to do this, few fall short, and end up feeling like "just another point and click" derived of any rich narrative. Primordia is not one of those games that falls short at all.I should admit before I go any further that I've only played the opening sequence of this game thus far, and am extremely excited to get back to it after this review, but this particular summary will be noting the aesthetic, and initial response of Primordia.I absolutely love post-apocalypse. It's not an uncommon scenario, thankfully, so there's lots of material to dig through on the subject. Unfortunately, there's quite a lot of BAD post-apocalypse games out there, and so with some hesitation, I bought this game, and sat down with some skepticism. For ten bucks, I was hoping it was going to deliver, and the reviews spoke for themselves.Primordia does something a lot of post-apocalyptic stories don't, and removes humans altogether from the character roster. You begin the game as Horatio Nullbuilt (the surname meaning some dude presumeably named 'Null' built him, which is a common theme throughout the game), the 5th version to be precise, and are accompanied by Crispin Horatiobuilt, your custom companion and comic relief. The world around you is an age-old Earth, looking very barren and very post-war. A strange robot cuts down your door one day and steals your power core, without which you can not charge your own batteries (nor Crispin's). Since that simply won't do, you venture out into the world in order to find the strange robot and reclaim your power core. Easier said than done. What follows are scenes common to Adventure/Point+Click games: You meet hosts of interesting robots, travel to new and exciting places, and spend a good deal of time trying to combine every single item in your inventory to see if it does something cool. Excellent (okay... MOSTLY excellent) voice acting, a (so far) riveting and comedic script, beautiful artwork, and intriguing characters make this one of my favorite Adventure games to date, and I've barely even started it.Should you get it? I mean, it's a point and click. You know what you're getting. The deciding factor, in most cases, is the story and artwork, and both deliver wholeheartedly. Even this early, the story is already showing to be incredibly promising, with twists and turns, and dark comedy as only robots can deliver. The script, as mentioned, is really quite good, and I don't find myself simply reading through the subtitles and clicking through in order to progress, but rather relishing the lines and the delivery. The art, while simple and "retro" in style, does not detract at all from the story, but actually enhances it with far-off vistas, incredible robot designs, and teeming robot cities, both very alive, and strangely dead. Fans of point and clicks, this is another excellent addition to your collection, reminding me of titles like Deponia, Riven, and (of course) Monkey Island. Fans of sci-fi, post apocalyptic fiction will also love this game. All in all, I think it's one of those rare games on Steam where I feel like I absolutely got what I paid for, and then some.And I haven't even finished it.

Posted: January 2
												TL;DR:It's a PCA (Point and Click Adventure). No actual puzzles, just good old-school inventory combining and environment clicking!Graphics:     8/10 (Sub-HD resolution. All the scenes, characters and animations are VERY well drawn/animated.)Sound:       10/10 (Fully voiced, fully music'd, and it's all high-quality. Doesn't get better!)Interface:     9/10 (Art'ed menus that fit the game; intuitive and minimalistic.)Story:           8/10 (Engaging, entertaining, fascinating and everything is tied together. Nice!)Characters:  9/10 (Horatio reminds me of Ben from Full Throttle. Crispin is quite entertaining, deep "B" listers, too!)Toughness:  5/10 (Security through Obscurity. Score with autohints off. Discworld = 10/10, for reference).Length:        7/10 (Took me 12h to beat without hints. I liked it and didn't want it to end!)Overall:        9/10 (Great fun if you like PCAs, post-apocalyptic themes, robots, and a fun sidekick!)Thanks for a rather great PCA! I'd really like to see a HD version sometime, but it's still totally worth it!

												A great point and click adventure through and through. The art style is fitting, the voice acting is great and the puzzles are generally logical and fun. Posted: December 31, 2016
												HOLY COW!!! Through out the game I kept remembering how it felt to play Riven and Myst. It has been MANY years since then and for a modern game to take me back to my childhood like that is one of MY first signs of a great game. The puzzles, the dialog, the art, the interface, and the music... I could not have asked for better. Definatlly on my top 5 BEST puzzle games of all time. I actually care about what happens to each character. Try you hardest to solve the puzzles on your own, they are VERY rewarding. Also take care there are more than just a couple endings.

Posted: January 1
												The game gripped me shortly after beginning. My heater was broken, it was freezing outside. But this wonderful adventure had hooked me. The world is one of the best-presented I've ever seen. The characters are very well presented to make you curious for more. I just wanted to spend more time exploring this world. It's also filled with humor that lightens up the somber setting, it's difficult to explain just how well the combination works.The puzzles themselves vary in quality, with some doing a great job in feeling like you're just solving problems that would exist in the world rather than an arbitrary roadblock by the developers. Others... Not so much. One particular puzzle stands out as an example of this problem (slight spoiler warning, though I won't give the answer)You need two different objects that can obstruct a vent. The first is easily gained by cutting off the tip of a robot's finger. However, the game doesn't allow you to cut off the tip of another finger for the second item. This is a frustrating limitation, and can easily lead to resenting the puzzle. The fact that important objects are often indistinguishable from the background only adds to the frustration.HOWEVER, and I can't stress this enough, while this kind of uneven quality in puzzles should suck the fun out of an adventure game... It doesn't. The rest of the world is too entrancing. It single-handedly rekindled my love of adventure games. I bring up these drawbacks to help emphasize how truly great the rest of the experience is, that even these issues don't sour it.TLDR; If you're considering buying this game, do so. Do it now. Play it. Enjoy it. Have fun.

Posted: July 15, 2014
												This game is underrated in my opinion. If you like Point&Click Adventure games and haven't played this yet, definitely do. It has hard puzzles (sure - I might have taken a look in a walkthrough once or twice), great general geeky humor, robots, amazing voice acting (Logan Cunningham of Bastion!), beautiful pixely art style (try 640x480 on a 27" monitor, it's great). Oh and did I mention robots?Once I started I couldn't stop playing until the early morning. But even once you're done, you're not done. Posted: July 21, 2014
												Overall satisfying adventure game with only a few caveats.  Most of all I recommend this game.  Pros: • Thought-provoking story full of moral ambiguities and juxtaposed viewpoints making you question your own judgments of the characters and their actions.• Good interface with a minimum of unnecessary clicking and waiting.• Varied endings dependant on choices made by the player.• Interesting scenery, good voice acting, and excellent atmosphereic soundtrack.Cons: • Completely unnecessary gender references at various points.  It's a world full of robots... Why does there need to be a "female" robot with boob-curves, or gender binary relationship references between androgynous mechanoids?• Serious tone somewhat undermined by numerous 4th-wall jokes by  a main character.• Lots of back-tracking and occasionally preposterous leaps in logic were needed to solve puzzles.  Several times I found myself resorting to "randomly combine junk until something happens" or having to look up walkthroughs, and being utterly baffled how someone would arrive at that solution.As stated above, I do highly recommend this game, and I enjoyed the story.  You should check it out!

Posted: July 27, 2014
												I revived a giant war robot by sticking its finger up its nose 11/10.In all seriousness though, this game is beautiful. The story is wonderful and moving, the characters are well-written and fleshed out, and the humor is surprisingly funny despite the game's bleak dystopian setting. The art and backgrounds, though they look somewhat dated and old-fashioned, are still detailed and do a very good job building the world and creating the atmosphere. The puzzles were a little hard to figure out at times, but always had a logical solution. I strongly recommend this game to everyone, unless you're not much of a point-and-click fan or can't stand dystopian settings I guess. Seriously though, this game is amazing. You won't be disappointed.This game also happened to introduce me to Wadjet Eye Games and has sort of been a gateway drug into their other games. Which are also really good. I am ok with that.

Posted: December 15, 2014
												A fantastic world. Melancholy, but with as much hope as you are willing to make. I did NOT expect some of the endings, nor that there would be so many.But if you choose one of the good endings, I foresee  definite  sequel potential, especially if you investigate thoroughly and read/watch the official short story prequel "Fallen".  Think of a cross between the shows "Firefly" and "The 100". Unfortunately, the developers have slipped up  majorly  in their commentary mode. Some words unfit to be spoken or heard (as in, the absolute worst the English language can offer), tarnishing Primordia's otherwise shining image. Posted: December 27, 2014
												Wow. What an incredible little game. This is the second point and click adventure I've ever completed and it was worth every penny. If I'm not mistaken this game was Greenlit on Steam, Wormwood Studios is an Indie developer with a lot of support in the GOG community. The style and apocalyptic hand painted backdrops of each space is nothing short of awe inspireing. I didn't even mind having to play in a lower res and sacrificing my second screen to play this game. Very cool story line and excellent sound score kept me gripped 'til the end. If this game looks interesting to you, do yourself a favor and try it out, especially if it's on sale, you just might love it, ya dingus!p.s. The song on Horatio's phonograph "Dreams Of Green" by Kim Beokbinder and Nathaneil Chambers is one of the most haunting and beautiful compisitions reflecting a post apocalytpic landscape that I've heard, Only proof that behind any great game, there needs to be great music. Wormwood Studios, I hope this isn't the last Primordia title, thank you guys for this piece of art.

Posted: March 16, 2014
												I’m a sucker for graphical adventure games, though they don’t always pan out. All the same, Wadjet Eye hasn’t let me down yet. This one’s a bit of a different take. Basically, the human race is gone and all we’re left with is machines just trying to get by and survive. Unfortunately, there’s not a whole hell of a lot else I can say because I haven’t played this one much.  So why recommend it, then? First and foremost, everything is dripping in ambience.The artwork, animation, sounds, music…all of it is perfect and fitting. In a way, it almost reminds me of New Vegas in that you are nomadic and are forced into going into “the city” at an eventual point that only serves to further the plot with all kinds of twists.  Nevermind that there are returning voice actors from other Wadjet Eye titles that do an outstanding job and the puzzles are no joke…though not necessarily heavy-handed either. Again, I haven’t played too much into it, but the game is cheap and a definite throwback to earlier graphical adventure titles. I highly recommend it.

Posted: December 15, 2014
												A fantastic world. Melancholy, but with as much hope as you are willing to make. I did NOT expect some of the endings, nor that there would be so many.But if you choose one of the good endings, I foresee  definite  sequel potential, especially if you investigate thoroughly and read/watch the official short story prequel "Fallen".  Think of a cross between the shows "Firefly" and "The 100". Unfortunately, the developers have slipped up  majorly  in their commentary mode. Some words unfit to be spoken or heard (as in, the absolute worst the English language can offer), tarnishing Primordia's otherwise shining image. Simply don't pry in commentary mode and you'll be golden.For the game proper, I recommend this mechanical crisis of faith.

Posted: March 16, 2014
												This is the best games I've been playing for years (and I'm playing AC4 now).It has a great depth, plot, atmosphere and length (maybe a little too short).Playing Primordia was like meeting an attractive, inteligent woman :)It was a pleasure, a well spent time, a lot of thinking - thinking about life, world around me, Ukraina and Russia, my role in it etc.I recommend this game to every thinking human, every adventure game fan, every cyberpunk fan.It's an art, not a simple game and it should be rewarder for it!

Posted: March 16, 2014
Click Here for the Full Review! [monthsbehindreviews.blogspot.com]Synopsis: A fantastically simple little adventure game. Explore the ruins of Earth to find the fiend that stole your power crystal, the device you need survive. In the process, find out what happened to man, and your surprising role in the end of the world. Make choices that change the final results of the game, and tackle puzzles that can be, at times, a bit too challenging. Enjoy the humorous back and forth between the main character (voiced by the narrator for Bastion) and his flying sidekick. A great game to play in short bursts if you tend to get stuck, or in a longer sitting if you have the fundamentals of combining items in you inventory together to form the key piece you need.Multiple playthroughs, or saving at critical moments, are required in order to see all possible endings, of which, there are at least 7, but what happens after those possible ending scenarios depends on what you accomplished during the game - who  you saved, who you let die, etc. Took me about 7 hours during the first playthrough, largely because some of the puzzles are a bit tricky (oh, wait, I can use the Signal Transmitter on that blue light to solve this puzzle...huh.). A second playthrough took about a third of that time. I found the environment and story the game told, as well as the solidness of the gameplay, well worth my $2.50 investment, but it wouldn't be a bad deal to get it for a bit more than that, because I've rated this one 9/10.

Posted: December 5, 2014
												An artistic gem of a game, Primordia really hits the spot for an old school point and click adventure. What really draws you in is the unique story and interesting dialogue along with the sci-fi, post apocalyptic setting.Overall I really enjoyed this game, but there are definitely a few things that could have been improved. The game setup before you launch the game can only be accessed in the game folder and can't be launched in game or through steam. When the setup is run it's somewhat confusing and I always felt as if the graphics weren't set up right. Watching the trailer for the game confirms this when I see crisp, clean graphics on the store page and fuzzy, muddy graphics on mine and changing to higher settings just seemed to make it look worse. It seems though that that developers are continuing to make improvements, so maybe this can be fixed in the future.Balance in the game seemed a bit lacking as solving puzzles became an effort in frustration at times. Having your sidekick Crispin give you clues helped quite a bit, but even with his help some areas required random trial and error because you had no clue what to do. Without a little help from a guide I probably wouldn't have finished the game. Minor gripes aside though, I had a great time playing this game. With a quality soundtrack, voice acting and funny dialogue it was well worth it. Multiple endings helped keep it interesting a bit as well with radically different results to the storyline. Definitely a must play for point and click adventure fans.

Posted: December 27, 2014
												Wow. What an incredible little game. This is the second point and click adventure I've ever completed and it was worth every penny. If I'm not mistaken this game was Greenlit on Steam, Wormwood Studios is an Indie developer with a lot of support in the GOG community. The style and apocalyptic hand painted backdrops of each space is nothing short of awe inspireing. I didn't even mind having to play in a lower res and sacrificing my second screen to play this game. Very cool story line and excellent sound score kept me gripped 'til the end. If this game looks interesting to you, do yourself a favor and try it out, especially if it's on sale, you just might love it, ya dingus!p.s. The song on Horatio's phonograph "Dreams Of Green" by Kim Beokbinder and Nathaneil Chambers is one of the most haunting and beautiful compisitions reflecting a post apocalytpic landscape that I've heard, Only proof that behind any great game, there needs to be great music. Wormwood Studios, I hope this isn't the last Primordia title, thank you guys for this piece of art.

Posted: March 23, 2015
												I have tried to get into point and click adventure games in the past but have tired of them quickly. As soon as I get stuck the temptation to check for the solution on the web gets greater and when I finally do the magic is gone, I may as well just use the walkthrough. With Primordia there were some hard points but with the help of my sidekick Crispin I managed to get through and complete the game.I found the world incredibly absorbing. The artwork was excellent and the dialogue thoroughly amusing. The story pulls you in and at the end I was a little sad that it was over.If you like adventure games then this will be a hit. The things you need to interact with are generally easy to find on the screen and the dialogue and hints help a lot.

Posted: July 2, 2015
												Great game. The grungy cyber-punk story is right up my alley. It's cryptic and a bit hard some times, as point and click adventures should be, but I only got stuck once and you can't run into dead ends where you cant finish the game.Only issue I had was with the resolution, but with a quick google search on the issue all my problems were solved.Would recomend for any point and click adventure fans.

Posted: July 9, 2015
												     When I first saw this game, I was looking for something similar to machinarium (another point-and-click adventure game) and what I was met with while playing Primordia was not at all disappointing. There are some very unique things that set this game apart from other point-and-click adventure games.     One element that is so different about Primordia is the surprisingly large amount of dialogue that is incorporated into it, unlike most other games of the genre.     Another characteristic that adds to the game is Crispin, the protagonist's "sidekick" if you would call him that. He adds a sense of humour to the game (although sometimes rather corny) and can offer hints to the player that are valuable, but not always completely revealing of the next course of action that must be taken. Crispin is an often uplifting character in this post-apocalytic setting.     Another trait that won me over is the atmosphere in the game. It seems realistic in the post-apocalyptic setting, and it is one of my favorite things about this game. The backrounds always seem beautifully made.     The puzzles in this game are very engaging and are not always clear-cut which may seem like a bad thing, but I personally enjoy the extra challenge. Not every puzzle is as simple as clicking on one thing and then another. They often include various items and/or certain actions to be taken. This is a huge difference between Primordia and other point-and-click adventure games.     The only complaint I really have about this game is that it seems to include a few creationist concepts that I personally do not agree with. It is brought up through the concept of humanism in the game which is symbolic of today's major religions that believe that a god created humans.     Another piece of this game that I am not fully content with is the way the protagonist moves. It can sometimes seem somewhat clumsy, but I won't be critical about it seeing as how that is how it is with most other point-and-click adventure games.     Overall, I would give this game an 8.5/10. It is definitely a worthwhile play for those who like games such as machinarium or other big point-and-click adventure games because of the unique elements it includes.     One last thing I would like to address is that it sometimes has multiple choices that can be made, leading to different outcomes. They do not alwyas have a huge effect on the story, but it adds a sense of independence in the game.I highly recommend that you all look into playing this game :)

Posted: November 26, 2015
												I give it 8.5 / 10The puzzles provide a good challenge and the story is well written. I really enjoyed playing through this, unlike other point and click adventure games. The themes are also pretty dark, but very satisfying and aided in keeping me playing. I tend to put these kind of games down because I get bored or suck. I hated mine sweeper as a kid and randomly clicking around the screen got tiresome. Primordia even has some cheeky and cleaver dialogue incase you need to run around clicking everything. Didn't help with the frustration, but the occasional joke helped keep me from just giving up. Plus CYBERPUNK! PLUS POST APOCALYPTIC WASTELANDS!SPOILERS!!!!--------There are multiple endings. I assure you, saving right before the big confontation helps you experience them all! Each is pretty cool, but even some optional items can have an impact on the ending. Mainly items belonging to your companions. Also certain events may occur that have an impact on your endings. Save different files often as kind of a bookmark so you can go back and attempt for different outcomes. I had about 17 so I could see everything with three files for all the endings (confrontation save)  For example, there's a situation where you can corner a rogue AI. Save before you attempt! Trapping him gives you an item that aids in the true ending, but killing him changes the ending of that chapter. So if you want to experience both chapter endings, you'll need 2 saves, but after that, the two paths merge and continues normally. ALSO! SPOILERS!Have Crispin talk to the lanterns. He needs the practice!

Posted: July 12, 2015
												I couldnt pull myself away from this game! It was a real peice of nostalgia playing a 90s DOS-style point and click game. The graphics were very impressive, and keeping loyal to the distinct low-res 16-bit feel. The storyline is engaging with some interesting sub-text about human society. The puzzles are challenging enough to keep you wanting more, but never too challenging. The music was beautiful and really added to the sence of desolation. The only think i didnt like was some of the voice acting was a bit hammy. Other than that its a brilliant game!

Posted: November 21, 2015
												ACTUALLY a good point-n-click with the charm and feel of a puzzle game from the golden days.Lots of comedy, lots of despair, the world feels real and you really do feel like you need to win the game for the good guys, as absurd as that might sound.Great visuals, great humor, great writing, great game!

Posted: December 13, 2015
												Great game. Everything that a point and click RPG should be. I enjoyed the variance in puzzles and that they weren't all given to you without work. I lso liked to ability play with minimal help or lots of it, depending on the puzzle. There were a few puzzles that had harder to follow or find peices than I liked, but it may have just been me. Overall, I greatly enjoyed the experience and would recommend it to anyone.

Posted: October 7, 2016
												This game was surprisingly amazing. Not only does it look and work like a great 90's point and click game like Full Throttle, it actually FEELS like one. While playing it I constantly forgot that it wasn't a classic game from decades ago. The art, story, characters, dialogues and puzzles are all fantastic. The past years I haven't had much patience for these kinds of games (even though I used to love them) mostly because I can rarely get engaged enough with the story and characters to keep playing and paying attention to long conversations. In Primordia every single piece of dialogue is very interesting and mysterious, revealing more about the world and its history, or it's just plain witty and funny. The puzzles are great too, very intuitive most of the time. The hint system is pretty good too, not breaking immersion and sometimes just the right push in the right direction. I used hints a few times and rarely felt like I was cheating, so that's pretty great.TL;DR - Primorida is an amazing game, but <SystemUser> is welcome to select their own terminology.

Posted: November 10, 2016
												First off, I highly recommend this game.Pros:  Fun play experience, decent storytelling, fairly decent voicing of characters, game was priced fairly well.Cons: Some of the clickables in game aren't readily apparent and in one instance incredibly easy to overlook (elevator control panel at one point in game is a prime example). The game is short (I really wish it had been longer, I didn't want it to end. The game is able to be completed in under 2 hours.)It's pretty rare when I find a game that I enjoy as much as this one.  It is fairly reminiscent of Septerra Core, which is a major plus.  The game is well polished and priced quite well for the level of enjoyment you get playing it.

Posted: December 15, 2016
												One of the best Point and Clicks I've ever played.

Posted: October 9, 2016
												Some puzzles are fairly easy because you know you got everything you need and must make it work somehow.Others are terrible - the flipped ship, the rag that takes long to discover, the overall logic of the puzzles. One time you try to search the junk and your character says there's nothing in there of interest, next time you find something in there. When I get told: "This is all crap", then I dont expect this to magically transform suddenly to the puzzle solution. Games usually separate between useless and useful. The useless is for decoration mostly. These NPCs are called "workers", so there's not much to gain from them, but one of them has a name, so the player knows he's useful to progress in the story. These items are used to progress, others are just junk, decoration and so on. Usually the main character makes clear quickly what they are. You know you can look at them but never use them. I hate when a game ♥♥♥♥♥ on this and abuses well etablished ways for orientation as some kind of puzzle.Lots of the stuff in the inventory looks like the weird crap it is, how do I know how I am supposed to use it? So I just try everything with everything until something works, and if nothing does, I just try everything in my inventory on everything in the outside world, which sometimes is a problem because the developers thought it's fun to search for hot spots.Usually adventure games have a button to reveal them, not here though. I don't like pixelhunting at all, and I think old games, especially adventures, were mostly way too cryptic and way too complicated. I don't even call it hard, for me it's simply bad game design when you are clueless of what to do next once again. I wouldn't use bad game design as example of how to make a game unnecessarily complicated.Usually in games you can figure out by some logical thinking - where do I go from here? What can I try? What item could go with which item? What am I doing AT ALL and WHY? Why am I accessing a giant robot again? Why like this? Why do I have to access a bomb again that also is a religious shrine somehow AND a powercore? Why again do I have to attach graphite to a cat with granny's panty hose to blow up a mailbox?? It doesn't have to be this way. I've played games where every next step makes sense through the WHOLE GAME and not only a few parts. It's not that the puzzles in Primordia are super hard to solve, it's just an overload of stuff. Especially of numbers. I think using plenty of numbers/codes is the lame way to create difficulty. Add some annoying minigames, like power cord connection and machine assembling. Ugh. Hand me the walkthrough! Despite that, the game has great atmosphere, really good voice acting, I like the humor and sound design, and I'd still recommend it.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												If you're a fan of point and click adventure games, this is definitely something you should pick up. Primordia has excellent characters, a fantastic story, and the graphics are definitely up to par for the game. A few of the puzzles can be a bit tricky, but none are too difficult to necessitate a walkthrough. The game also features multiple endings, which is a definite plus.

Posted: April 3, 2016
												This may just be the best freaking adventure game I have ever played in my life!The game manages perfectly to keep you interested, but not overwhelming you.And if you're stuck, you can always get help that REALLY HELPS from your Pal Crispin.I HATE it when I need a strategy guide, only to get passed some roadblock of a puzzle,like in most other adventures.Not so here.Multiple ways to solve puzzles.Multiple outcomes to situations.Multiple ENDINGS ! - I love it.And the attention to detail is really striking, - not ONCE did I encounter a single line of dialogue that didn't fit, although that's something developers quite ALWAYS glitch up in a minor way whenallowing their game to follow multiple paths.On top of that, FOR ONCE an adventure game orients itself in reality, in the sense that you can use the same item in different but similar situations - most other games just find one excuse after the other, why "Crowbar XY" can IN NO WAY open Door #2, when just minutes ago it was  perfectly capable of opening Door #1.In Primordia things tend to be a little more logical, and I enjoyed every minute of it.I played it straight through today, then immediately run through it a second time, just to collect the achievements and see all the things I could have missed.

Posted: December 29, 2016
												Primordia is a retro-styled point and click adventure game set in a dystopian future in which Man has gone extinct. Only machines remain, struggling to survive in the junk-filled wastelands. The protagonist will have to face many challenges in order to retrieve his source of power, gradually learning about the hidden thruth of his world along the way.The gameplay is very simple, as is every other adventure game: you'll have to explore, find and combine multiple items and use them at the right places to progress. What separates this game from the others is it's theme and its great humor. The last being delivered by a lovable sidekick who also serves the purpose of a hint bot. The puzzles are clever and challenging but not impossibly hard. The story is filled with rich and interesting lore, but is very linear (except at the very end, where you have multiple endings available). Each dialogue feels thought out and unique.The graphics are very reminiscent to those of Fallout 1: pixelated and low-resolution with dark brownish tones, which is tolerable since they seemed to be aiming for the retro theme. The only exception is the handful of brief cutscenes presenting very detailled close-ups of the action, which help with the immersion. The soundtrack is atmospheric and blends well with the setting. The voice acting is truely amazing.There's even some replayability value for those who wish try the commentary mode.So in short; for a 7 hour game with a good storyline and challenging puzzles paired with immersive soundtrack and great voice-acting, the pricetag is well worth the experience.

												Primordia was an impulse buy of mine during the Steam winter sale, and I'm very glad I gave it a shot. The puzzles were surprisingly difficult and the choices you make as a player actually have some weight. Posted: June 11, 2014
												I've been playing a lot of indie point-and-clicks lately; Primordia stands out because of its writing and setting. It has a LucasArts Loom vibe to it, with the protagonist Horation NullBuilt conjuring up an idea of what Bobin Threadbare would be if he was competent and decided to use his amnesia to his advantage. Yes, both characters have amnesia, have lost their home communities, and the fabric of society quite literally rests on their creations. Elements of the story definitely seem similar. The setting of Primordia is more exciting. It's a colorful combination of dystopia, cyberpunk, and steampunk. While that mix is becoming more and more common these days, finding 'good' games in that genre is still rare.I mentioned the writing: the story is captivating if only to explore the lore, and the main plot-arc is mediocre. The dialog writing is where the game shines; Horatio's sidekick levitating robot Crispin is a very well written NPC that integrates into the game nicely. The character is used to solve some puzzles, though not too much, and offers rather direct walkthrough-type tips if the protagonist is stuck.With it's marvelous writing, I wanted Primordia to feature more NPCs and dialog quests. A particular stand-out quest involves a logic puzzle attempting to legally assign the surname of a pet robot. While the logic is difficult to follow without pen and paper handy, the writing and voice-acting attempts to seduce the player away from choosing the logical option and I was tempted to go down a logically-flawed path (which the game teased would result in different endings and impact late-game quests). Rarely does game-dialog inspire this anymore, and it is where indie games such as Primordia stand a cut above the rest.The game has a relatively short playthrough and the puzzles become more difficult, sometimes to the level of ridiculousness, later in the game. This is caused by the game too early allowing me to use multiple items for different quests, and in the late game suffering through trying every permutation of item combination to solve the puzzles. Nonetheless, I would recommend this game to a casual or hardcore adventure gamer, as it is both enjoyable and tells a well-written, albeit cliche story.

Posted: December 14, 2013
												Primordia does 2 things well: dialogue and environment. Despite the less than crisp resolution of the game, the backgrounds and landscapes are imaginative and beautiful. The dystopian world is set post-human inhabitation, and robots--having gained self-sufficiency--are the survivors. Interactions are varied, and the clash of philosophies keeps you interested. It is an alien world, one that I was happy I visited.I needed a guide to get through this game. Solving puzzles requires assistance or large amounts of time. Direct question puzzles were difficult. Seriously difficult. I was able to figure them out because I have enough probability knowledge to know how to crunch the numbers. Otherwise, I got stuck, alot. The technical jargon naming of items, though justifiable, made some item combo puzzles vexing. I did not even know what some words meant, and few times I would simply not even try.It lasts about 6-8 hours, and is a fun ride. It harkens back to Monkey Island and other wonderful point-and-click adventures, but it also brings the same frustrations. Regardless, it is worth the asking price for a weekend game.

Posted: December 10, 2016
 So what happens  after  the robots take over the world?  Primordia  is here to answer that question. This amazing point-and-click game takes place on a dystopian Earth at an unspecified point in history. The few humans that remain have fled underground, living in low-g bunkers and looking at a once-green Earth through pictures and little garden chambers. Over the years, we have faded into myth, and now the Earth is ruled by our creations, some of who worship our memory as a creed called "Humanism."You are Horatio Nullbuilt, a wasteland-dwelling robot of undeterminate origin whose only companion is Crispin Horatiobuilt, a floating, armless robot with an endless supply of sarcastic remarks. Together, they lived a pretty uneventful life. They were trying to fix up a crashed airship, a relic of the long-forgotten War of the Four Cities, so they could at last fly away from the Dunes and go wherever they want. Unfortunately, their progress is halted when a mysterious robot named Scraper shows up and "plunders" their power core--an item they cannot survive without. When trying to find power in the Dunes fails, they have no choice but to travel to Metropol, the last city, where their power core has been taken. To make matters worse, an anceint robot named MetroMind has claimed your power core for the betterment of the city, since it is crumbling under her inept rule and she needs all the power she can get.From there, it is up to you how the story ends. Choose carefully, your every move has consequences.The voice-acting is masterfully done. Every character is unique and full of personality. The story and lore are very well-crafted as well. Unraveling the mystery of the world you're in never fails to be fascinating, and if you play through it just right, the ending is beautiful and cathartic.Like my review? Check out my  Curator  page!

It's not an easy jorney and not a hard-core point-n-click experience, it's in a sweet spot, golden middle. The game is rated "Overwhelmingly Positive" by community and this is really deserved.
