Posted: July 30, 2016
												Though challenging at times, the solutions always made logical sense. Primordia is one of the best point-and-click games I have had the pleasure to play through. You are Horatio Nullbuilt, a robot who essentially spends his life dumpster-diving and building from what he can find. Likewise, every piece of information gathered through dialogue and observation has a purpose. This game isn't just "put this on that and see if it works" and it never hands you the answers unless you ask (Crispin acts as an in-game hint giver), and even then, solutions are never simply GIVEN. Crispin is like a hand that'll guide you to the right area, but won't tell you what to do when you're there. Loved the story. I wish there was a sequel.

Posted: February 2, 2016
												I thought Primordia was a very good game, and I would recommend it both in terms of mechanics and story. I am a big fan of the Blackwell games, and this game has many of the same strengths.Pros:+ Excellent story. There's legitimately a lot to think about in this game, including political, religious, and social commentary. The game is set in a world where humans are extinct and only robots are left. We see how the society they create is a very clever mirror of our own, with plenty of parody of our own flaws along the way.+ The point and click puzzles are solid. They are somewhat difficult, but solvable without having to consult a walkthrough because the solutions make sense once you get them. To me, this is one of the most important things about gameplay in a point and click. You have to use your brain to solve the puzzles.+ If you do start struggling, you can get hints by talking to people (especially your sidekick Crispin), which again means you don't need to consult the internet to get a nudge in the right direction. Normally, he will give you a clue about which area you should be searching, or which object you should be fiddling with.+ The art and aesthetics in the game are good. The characters are interesting-looking, and the world is very neat.+ The game is paced well. It does a nice job of moving you from place to place, advancing the story and revealing the mysteries by steps.Cons:- Hard to think of any. I suppose the UI can be a bit clunky until you get used to it, especially how you access your inventory.

												A highly polished, fully voiced retro adventure game with an engaging post apoctalyptic sci-fi story. Lasts about 6-8 hours depending on how long it takes you to figure out the puzzles. Posted: January 4
												This was an impulse buy while it was on the Steam winter sale, and it was one of the best impulse buys I've ever done.There is something truly unique and amazing about this game, and if you're reading this and wondering whether or not you should buy it, let me give you the rundown.Excellent:-The story is compelling, and populated with incredibly unique characters. One of my favorites is a fairly minor character that speaks in a religious cadence, and it's just such a cool little scene, it really stuck with me.-The characters are diverse and incredibly easy to become attached to. They are so well written, that you could name a character from hearing just a TINY snippet of their dialogue.-There are some truly genius puzzles here that absolutely blew me away. -The art is pretty breathtaking. The whole game feels alien and strange, but a familiar shadow seems to hang over it. It's just ♥♥♥♥ing great.Meh:-The voice acting for both Horatio and Crispin, the two main characters, is a little...off. Horatio I kind of got used to, and his monotone drone ended up being more part of his personality than anything, but Crispin has some pretty well-written lines that are delivered pretty awkwardly, and I found him pulling me back out of the game a little bit every so often. That being said, Crispin is delightful, if a tad annoying.-Some of the puzzles are absolutely rediculous, with some of them being outright pixelhunting. With as intelligent as the rest of the game is, it makes these puzzles even HARDER, because you expect the answer to make more sense. For instance (No spoilers here, don't worry.)     There is a part of the game where your path is impeded, and the answer is the first thing that comes to your mind: "Crispin should just move that." And that is, indeed, the answer to that quandry.     There's a part where you need to find an item, but you aren't told where it can be found or where to start. Had to resort to a walkthrough on this one, because the answer lay in a very cluttered, dark area of the screen. You never think "This game will resort to pixel hunting", because the rest of the game is just...too well thought out.So most of my complaints are "Come on, Primordia, you're BETTER than this!", which should absolutely tell you something. How this isn't a HUGELY known game is beyond me.In conclusion: Buy it, you son of a ♥♥♥♥♥.

Posted: September 21, 2014
												I really loved Primordia it took me back to the days when Sierra, Revolution and Lucas Arts created some truly unique games and Primordia stands perfectly in their company. The voice acting is very good and there is a lot of humorous references to pop, computing and gaming culture. Primordia gives the player many choices for a game in this genre with various ways to solve puzzles and multiple endings that have very different outcomes. A few puzzles might be considered difficult, but most will keep you entertained without causing frustration. It took me about 8 hours to finish before going back to try different solutions to see the all the endings. I think Primordia is well worth the asking price and I found it more enjoyable than some newer click adventures 2-3 times more expensive. If you enjoyed games like Beneath A Steel Sky, The Dig or Ring World you won't be disappointed in Primordia.

Posted: October 3, 2014
												A fantastic point-and-click adventure brimming with atmosphere and clever puzzle design, with barely any flaws to speak of.So let's get those out of the way first. The biggest flaw is that the game occasionally has pixel-hunting puzzles, which are never good. Bad developers. Only time in the game I looked at guides was when I was missing something from pixel hunting (random LCD screen, bah, random floating junk, what even?)The palette's also a bit dull overall; I get the point of having so much brown but it gets a little tiring to look at after a while, though the game's gorgeous looking otherwise.That aside, only the postitives left. The two protagonist characters each have quite a bit of personality to them and play off each other well for plenty of amusing moments, though the game still keeps a fairly serious and dark tone throughout. The other various characters are all quite unique and memorable and serve the overall plot in interesting ways, usually having their own mini-arcs. The backstory and worldbuilding is also very rich, not outright saying a lot but leaving the pieces scattered for the player to put together. The puzzles are also generally good. Plenty of the standard item-trading things but there's no moon logic present there. And there's straight up logic puzzles on occasion, too, which are probably the most fun. There's no need to memorize strings of numbers or information, either; the game auto-saves all relevant data in the main character's datapouch, as well as providing a map for quick travel. It's got a lot of old-school adventure game design with a more modern feel to it, making it both well-crafted and elegant in execution.There's a lot to like here and little to dislike, I heavily recommend it to, well, pretty much anyone really, but especially point-and-click enthusiasts, because this is certainly top-tier in that regard.

Posted: October 8, 2014
												I hate point and click adventure games. . . I find them to be obtuse and difficult for no real reason. On the other hand, I had to play this one. It looks incredible, the vibe is so amazing... I still boot it up just get to back into the feeling that this game sets. Game play is as expected for a point and click I suppose ... click on a lot of things, combine them in ways that make no sense. The story is excellent, the humor is witty... this game gets a 9/10 for me just because of the atmosphere alone.  . . oh and dont forget the incredible gritty sound track.

Posted: January 12, 2015
												By far, one of the better (if not best) Point and Click games I've ever played. With several hidden easter eggs, a unique, well written, and deeply entrancing Storyline, and several well written jokes to lighten the mood at times. You grow to care about the charactors, and there are many paths and options, including multiple endings and even ending outcomes. Your actions define the end of the game, from early choices all the way down to the final and last choice you make, all add to overall feeling of completion when you see the ending cutscene.The soundtrack is no slouch and helps build atmosphere and keeps a very "Wizards" end of the world vibe throughout. There is even a Graphic novel about the game (search Youtube~)  Brass tacks; If you like simple to play but rewarding games, well written storys, funny banter, well placed and iconic Easter Eggs, multiple solutions to problems, and even small yet interesting side stories, you will love this game. For a simple point and click, its got a lot to offer. Well worth the buy.  I completely Support and recommend this game~

Posted: March 20, 2015
												I'll start this review by saying that this is the best point-and-click game I've ever played in my entire life.What makes this game so special is how the story develops and the awesome caracther design.SPOILER ALERT:The story begins with Horatio and Crispin on top of the UNNIC, a half broken airship that has seen better days.Horatio is fixing the telescope on that resides on top of said ship, when suddenly he hears a strange noise comming from down bellow.Appon entering the room, he is now faced with the fact that there is a giant robot that has claws and shoots lasers ( you will probably get the joke if you have played the game ) that invaded his ship by cutting a hole in it.The giant robot demands that Horatio "forfeits" and that he hands over his power core, Horatio does not give in to the robots demands and the following shoots Horatio in the chest region with a lazer beam.From then on, Horatio and his side kick crispin set off to find out who this robot was and where he went, so that they can get their power core back.Now let me tell you something, at this point I was already hooked on the story and I was like "okay let's continue playing for a bit more". That "bit" more turned into hours and hours of continuously playing this game. This game just throws at you the mix of a great story line + good caracther development + Not too hard to figure out but still good puzzles and great comedy. It doesn't have the same funny tone all the time howeverWhen Horatio and Crispin fail to find a power source in the wastelands they are forced to head to Metropol, the self proclamed city of glass and light. "Free power for one and all" is what they advertise and they do have power for everyone, but it does come with a price. When Horatio and Crispin step out of the red line train, Horatio finds a robot who collects 1 megacycle from him. At the time, Horatio has no idea of what a megacycle is, but he does find out eventually that the megacycles are brain power, we could also call it processing power. Anyways, the story goes along and Horatio finds out that his power core is stored on the big tower where Metromind is. He then goes on to try and get it back and that's when things take a darker turn. BUUUUUT I don't want to spoil the ending for anyone who might have read the spoil alert and then thinks to theirselfs "you know what, Imma read it anyways".The story is great, the caracthers are great, the puzzles are excellent and there are multiple endings which means you can replay the game and let me tell you, you will want to replay the game because it is so damn good!I would rate it an honest 9.5/10 , I would even dare to give it a 10/10 .Amazing game and for 10 euros, it is a bargain of a lifetime

Posted: May 28, 2015
General Overview: Primordia, a point and click adventure, takes place in the unique timeline of post-apocalyptia where humans are no longer present. The only thing left is their own invention: machine. Machine that prospered and slowly became just like human, with their own ideas and vices. Even if they're limited by their programming, they could still interact with others like normal folk. Taking the reigns of Horatio Nullbuilt and Crispin, what starts as a simple retrieval turns into a full blown adventure, albeit a somewhat short trip.Gameplay: The game itself follows the point and click style of gameplay, so its hard to screw that part up. That said, it does a good enough job being difficult and leaving you wondering "what the hell do I do now?" Thankfully, Crispin has a built in hint-o-tron to give you tips on what you could do or should do if you're ever stumped. The puzzles themselves are, in my opinion, pretty darn easy. The only difficult ones would be where you meet your unfriendly thief again or when you need access to a certain place with a long string of code. Other than that, it's pretty straight forward. Then again, I play puzzles for kicks so take that with a grain of salt. There are some puzzles with different methods of completion, usually a good and bad way. Sometimes the bad way is the only obvious way, where the good way will require a save here and there to help you out should you pull an oopsie. By the way, you'll probably be doing this often. Puzzles do have "soft-fail" states, which can be pretty infuriating, so save often! The actual game itself is, unfortunately, pretty damn short. You could probably finish the entire game within 5 hours or so (after knowing everything and everyone and all the choices). There is A TON of going back and forth. No joke, you'll probably find yourself going back and forth between robots, trying everything, for a good 10 minutes until something works. It can get annoying fast. There are also a few references sprinkled here and there to earn a few chuckles. Some more obvious than others.Art: Holy hell, this art style. While a mess of browns, it works so damn well together. Not to mention Horatio and Crispin always seem to stand out from the environment whenever possible, so that's also a plus. Unfortunately, the overwhelming abundance of browns makes finding some robots or items kinda difficult. Had to pull the hover method to find a few things sometimes. I understand its supposed to be post-apocalyptia, but sometimes you have to look away and rub your eyes.Music: It's amazing. Done.Acting: The VA in this game are beautiful and, at the same time, somewhat phoned in. Sometimes you can tell the lines are being read from the script. Other times you feel it from the heart. It is, overall, a very good experience to feel the voices actually try when they do. Funnily enough, it was the side characters that, in my opinion, had the best acting compared to our main characters.Overall, I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone that loves a good point and click adventure with a fan♥♥♥♥ingtastic sound track.

Posted: April 11, 2015
												Truly a master piece point click adventure game which has learned and adapted from all it's former predecessors. If you're interested in an old styled point click adventure which preserves the "vintage" feel of the genre, while making mile stone improvements to its execution -- then this is for you. Everything in this game made sense, I only used the walkthrough a small amount of times. The side kick is actually useful, he even hints you if you get stuck. The characters felt real and alive, things were not too 'grindy' and the story was very captivating... I can't say enough good things. If you're thinking about buying this game then don't think twice, buy it.

Posted: April 17, 2015
												Wow, another great entry into this new golden age of adventure games. Primordia does so many things right, stuff that should be common in every game of this genre, like multiple solutions to puzzles, branching paths and multiple endings.Both the story and atmosphere are great, and Crispin, the sidekick, serves not only as a great jokester, but also as a nice hint system that ensures that we are not left wandering aimlessly, like in many old adventure games. The game is quite short, but it’s better for it, as it doesn’t suffer from overreach, and it achieves the goal of telling a good story and exploring interesting themes.There’s not many downsides to this game, but one particular puzzle, near the end of the game (involving a kiosk), annoyed me, and didn’t played by the same rules as the rest of the game. I also thought that the voice of Horatio never felt appropriate for a robot (it’s the same actor as the main character of Gemini Rue, but in that case it fit great) , but it’s just a minor quibble. The rest of the cast and characters are great.

Posted: May 5, 2015
												Usually I do not have the patience to play retro (i.e. pixelated) point-and-click adventures anymore, nevermind finish them. This one kept me going though and I played it all in one sitting. What kept me going? The setting and the story were original (at least they were to me) and engaging. The gameplay and puzzles were simple enough to not get tedious without being pure pushovers. Most importantly, though, the characters were interesting and absolutely beautifully voiced -- far superior to a recent so-called "AAA game" that I played where I grew to hate the characters. Not in Primordia: every character was great and the voice actors and sound design was perfect: Horatio, Crispin, Clarity, Ever-Faithful, Gimbal,  Goliath, Oswald, Primer, 187th, Memento Moribuilt -- so many awesome voices and dialogues that I enjoyed immensely.

												A fantastic sci-fi point an click, brilliant Gieger-esque Art Novau style and a sense of humour that worked.

Posted: June 14, 2015
												A refreshing original adventure game with strangely charming retro-graphics despite the desolate environments devoid of living things. You play as a robot in a post-apocalyptic world, where robots of varying degrees of sentience, function and design remain after humanity become extinct. Exploring and learning more about the world is compelling, the puzzles are well enough designed, you have a companion that is both useful and funny and the game is just long enough that it doesn't overstay its welcome. A small gem of an adventure game. Much recommended - don't let the seemingly crude and perhaps initially offputting graphics deter you.

Posted: July 24, 2015
												This B'sodding game was entertaining.  I miss these types of games of my youth.  This was a nice Throwback, and any fan of the style should check it out

Posted: July 26, 2015
												Just finished the game, was an interesting concept and a unique setting.  Hope there will be a sequel at some point.

Posted: June 16, 2015
												I LOVE post-apocalyptic dystopian stories like this!  The puzzles were challenging but fun, the dialogue was great (I never got tired of Crispin's quips), and the art was so cool!  I loved the style so much, it really suited the theme of the narrative perfectly.  I'm really glad I played this!

Posted: June 28, 2015
												Wonderful world building, engaging story, very simple and elegant interface, terrific voice acting. Highly recommended and well worth the time playing and the money to purchase. Definitely take the time to click anything and everything you can find. Also there are multiple endings and some quests it's easily possible to lock yourself out of if you're not careful (though the reasons you get locked out make sense to the storyline). Play through at least once and then check out a guide so you can make sure to see everything. I got every achievement and had a blast doing so.

Posted: July 6, 2015
												Play! You must! Go do it, now! This was my Point-and-Click cherry popper. I was super hesitant to play, as I'm used to fast paced action/adventure games, but I'm now hooked, and craving so much more than the amazing adventure Primordia offered. 15/10 would play again (Heck, I did the ending X amount of times to get the awesome death/ending achievements!)

Posted: July 15, 2015
												Damn good post-apocalyptic robot noir.  Reminded me of Alphaville and other bleak black-and-white post-war counter-modernist films.  I can't comment on the voice acting, because I play adventure games with voices turned off whenever possible (and so should you), but competent writing.  Varied locations and characters.  Multiple satisfying endings, and even the "happiest" is pleasantly bleak.  One of the best of the modern small-team adventure games (definitely better than Gemini Rue, which also was going for sci-fi noir).

Posted: August 22, 2015
												This game was a pleasant surprise, to be certain. I could tell just from looking at the trailer and screenshots of this game that it looked interesting, and that "Overwhelmingly Positive" next to the user reviews made it seem like a no-brainer. So, finally I picked up this game and boy, I am not disappointed.Let's get the bad out of the way first.This game runs in a very small resolution, at least for most modern monitors. The highest resolution possible is 1280x800, which looks best in a window. It was also a bit annoying that the only way I could find to change these settings was by a launcher in the actual folder containing the game files. I only found that much by perusing the game forum when I was disappointed with the resolution.There isn't much replayability. I can definitely see myself trying this game again to do a few things different, but overall it is a story-driven and therefore linear experience. It has several endings, but most of those endings are decided at your own whim by how you play out the final scenes.Now, the good.The obvious first thing you'll notice about this game is that artwork. I found it to be very cool to look at and definitely gives you that feeling of despair - a world wasting away around you as you desperately try to rebuild what you can. You also have atmospheric music that adds to these scenes but mostly stays in the background. It adds a lot, but doesn't overtake it. Instead, it's all just working together to give you an experience.The voice acting is likewise excellent. The main character and his sidekick both do most of the talking, so it's great to see them so well performed. It's easy to pick up on their personalities and they're both likeable.I'm always a bit bad at puzzles in games, but I thought the ones here were challenging but always possible. Nothing ever felt frustrating or beyond my abilities to figure out. I did get "stuck" in a few places where I had no idea what to do, but it usually came down to me not thinking about the situation well enough or remembering details that I simply overlooked. It's worth saying, almost everything matters in this game. There are few things that are superfluous.Overall it took me about six hours to complete this game. I would have liked for it to be longer, but I could say that for any good game.If you're interested in this game at all, check it out.

												This game was very good. I wish there were more games like this.

												one of the best point and click games i have ever played

Posted: November 16, 2015
												The only thing I hate about this game is that I didn't know about it sooner.

Posted: October 3, 2015
												The moment when you get to the bus-stop robot and hear the somber "I am waiting" with Blade Runneresque music in the background is priceless. It is a rarity among video games to have such an integral world with its lore and still be digestible. To be placed in a dark bleak world, yet to have a lot to interact with. This game is a must for all who enjoy dark sceneries and deeper philosophical themes.

Posted: October 23, 2015
												I don't write reviews often but this game warrants one.I highly recommend this game, It is a truely amazing experiance and you can see just how much dedication to every detail was given to this game. I haven't experianced a story that moved me as much as this in a long time! The world feels so alive and the puzzles and tasks feel meaningful not thrown together. This is the first point and click I ever finished to the end without using a guide, however this does not mean its easy just that the difficult challenges are fun and worth working through on your own.The characters, the art the atmosphere and music and the backstory just everything about this game is perfect and I am mourning its end as I could sit in front of my computer playing this forever.If you for what ever reason are on the fence about buying this masterfully crafted game please take my advice and just buy it. I would have paid double for this without hesitation.Thank you to the developers for this awesome game! and a round of applause to the artists and the voice actors as everything just fits perfectly!10/10 Buy it now or miss out.

Posted: October 27, 2015
												Beautiful pixel art is the crowning aspect of this game, just leaving it open and taking in the graphics are worth the price alone. The comedic dialogue is nicely written and acted although a bit out of place in the dismal Kinotrope-esque atmosphere of rusted machinery and manufactured wastelands. The graphics really are just stunning but as with many pointy clicky games it falls into the pitfalls of 1. having a great environment and concept but underdeveloped characters and 2. some of the puzzles just make no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sense. It's one thing to have difficult puzzles, I recently played armikrog and although it took me a while I still required no walk-through because it all followed some sense,  however with this game I needed walkthroughs multiple times only to find nonsense solutions that followed no logic, when it comes to puzzle structure I expected more from the creators of Gemini Rue. BUT I still did find myself really WANTING to advance to see more of the beautiful artwork and unique world-building shown in the game and I have to commend it for that. Overall I recommend it for the graphics alone but be prepared for the game's fair share of banana fishing rods and accordion bird vacuums.

Posted: December 14, 2015
												I have not played a point and click adventure game in a long time. Maybe since I was seven or ten either way I was really young.And being much older I looked down on this games and never give them a chance.But man do I feel stupid after playing this wonderful game.Not only is this a great game for many reason's but its done more then just play and run wonderfully.Its opened my eyes to what amazing storys and places are in all types of games not just your AAA titles.This game is why I love steam their's something for almost everone to enjoy and being someone whos super into mecha,robots, mechanical design, pixal art, and post apocalyptic setting this game hit all the right buttons.But for the game itself I will keep this simple.Its got amazing characters.Great voice acting.Amazing art and styling.Super interesting story and lore I can't get enough of.Gamplay is fun and inventive.And the sound design and soundtrack is just prefect.I really want to thank the people at Wormwood Studios and everyone who took the time, And effort to make this game.Thank you so much for making this game its an amazing title and made me open my eyes more to other cool and interesting games and made me love the imagintion of this wonderful industry even more so thank you.10/10 easily makes my top ten games I have ever played.

Posted: February 27, 2016
												My god. You want to talk about fun and story-driven gameplay? This thing comes close to a masterpiece. 9/10. Details below.Set in an extreme post-apocolyptia, our hero attempts to recover a power source he desperatly needs, stolen from him by a hulking robot. As his simple quest progresses, he finds himself drawn into the day-to-day conflicts of many men and women bots, deepening the story and lore of the world naturally. On the way you, the player, solve simple yet satisying point-and-click puzzles with elegent conectivity and solutions. The vast majority of the puzzles feel very natural, not forcibly integrated with the environment. The few esoteric ones can be figured out by paying careful attention to the dialogue of NPC bots. As you travel from your humble abode across vast wastes, to a sprawling, decrepit city, you meet incredibly interesting characters. The amount of work that went into the art design is astounding, and reflects well on the amount of work that went into the writing. The story is driven by dialogue rather than the environment, though all the scenes are breathtaking. I will say Crispin's playful banter leaves something to be desired and feels off-key, coming as it is in such a bleak game. But the story and gameplay merge so seemlessly you can forgive it. An incredible game with replay value and amazing choice endings. Highly reccomended.

Posted: July 29, 2016
												Ok I just finished this and first: this game was horribly crashing until I recently updated it, though unfortunately, I was already at the end of the game.The story is kind of...sad. Beautiful. The puzzles interesting and fun. I liked Technobabylon more though. Those ♥♥♥♥ing crashes ruined it for me to an extent...The end was just...hm. I miss the feeling of a final closure to the beautiful story. I revolted against MetroMind to the very end but the story ending was like....like the authors wished to finish the game early and stopped caring about the script. I sensed considerable laziness from the developers in the game, here and there, mainly in the story development. Not in the puzzles though, some of them were sure tough to solve - the kiosk was the worst hurdle and figuring out some codes literally hurt my head. Also, the puzzle where you need to answer two robots in answering three questions is broken...in the second question only though. You are asked which of selected statements MUST be true but all of the statements DO NOT NEED TO BE true so I had to find the answer online.Also, I'm not a good puzzle solver.All in all...this game DEFINITELY needs more story into it. And the story parts of "Humans destroyed themselves"? Cmon...that's lame. Human destroyed themselves / robots destroyed humans / wars between robots and humans....it's just not original. I mean: the Gospel of man, that is so beautifully written, I swear I read it many times. That is poetic. That was ART!! So was the philosophical laments of the MEMORIUS in the Kiosk. And Crispin! The Dunes! The Goliath!! All beautiful and very original, at least to me. Honestly, reading the gospel of man at the start of the game hyped me incredibly. I expected that the game was going to be preseting very hard, unsettling, maybe existential questions in its story. Conflict of religious beliefs among postapocalyptic robots? With philosophical insights and two-sided arguments I can relate to? I dig that. After reading the gospel of man at the start of the game, I realized that not only the author means the story, he is actually capable of meaning it! But...the story does not really go fully in this direction and remains a "beautiful adventure game" with a great story plot. At the start, I thought "this is going to be a masterpiece" but it was not. To be a masterpiece, it needs even more human soul given to it.

												Are you the sort of person who loves a good point and click, cyberpunk game where robots disscuss complicated politics, metaphysics, theology, Shakespeare and witty banter, all while wandering around a eerie dying earth setting where you try and make sense of a world populated by corrupt, demented machines? Posted: November 30, 2016
												Worth every penny. The game is just amazing, the voice acting, funny and smart dialogs, characters which will stay with you after you will finish, and world which is just mesmerizing. I just genuinly would love to see with my own eyes Metropolis and Dunes, and especially Goliath. And the art. The pixel art in this game just reminds me of Beksinsky work. It's beautiful, dark, full of gorgeous details. This game, for me at least, doesn't have any weak sides. The story is dark, and really gives lots of to think about. It's just a great game and everybody should give a try.

												The visual design really suits this game and provides a very immersive atmosphere, and to pair that up with such a captivating story, makes this truly an amazing game. It has you wanting for answers.. and when you finally get them, you'll be wanting for more, but that's all you're gonna get, it leaves the rest for you to wonder.Totally worth the 10€ I spent on this.

Posted: December 26, 2016
												Promordia is probably the best point-&-click i've played since the mid 90s.  The story, atmosphere and voice acting are all great but what REALLy set it's apart from modern point-&-clicks is that it is one, continuous game, not seperated in short episodes so you keep your stuff all the way through.  My only complaint is that it was too short but that is a great complaint to have.Also, room has been left to make a sequel, one that hopefully involve humans.

And that says a lot.I never expected this from a point and click game.The voice acting is flawless and the characters are really nicely made. Loved it to bits!

Posted: December 31, 2016
												Fun from start to finish, although I needed a hint for the "poem" puzzle.

Posted: December 29, 2016
												I liked this little game. It could be a little bit longer maybe but I guess I can still give it a second run later - with the developer commentary turned on and with trying to find out the solution for a few "side stories" i missed.  Puzzles and solutions did make sense which was quite refreshing. In a whole game there was only one point where I really needed to look the solution up*.Sometimes the game engine is a little choppy, especially in scenes with parallax scrolling attempts, which is funny with all the power computers have nowadays. I see the 320*200 -ish resolution is kind of intentional "retro style" but the engine does not have to :). After seeing some concept art which obviously was not low-res I even wonder whether it would harm the game If it was made in high resolution... The current result is still fine. So, I guess it was not the worst decision anyway.All in all, a very good adventure game. With the current Steam sale price any adventure games lover should give it a try.* The kiosk "puzzle": Art? Seriously, ART? It could easilly be any random word! :)

Posted: December 30, 2016
												If you enjoy dark dystopian sci-fi, beautiful artwork, and a storybook gameplay I highly recommend you try Primordia!As a point-and-click storybook game, Primordia does not dissappoint. It's smart, well-illustrated, and presents a compelling story. The writers took care to build an internally consistent world complete with mythology and believable motives. It's a world I would not be dissappointed to return to in a follow-up title. There is an obvious retro-feel that permeates not only the art style, but also the story and game-mechanic. Primordia's writing reminds me of 1980s robot sci-fi including a few text-based games from that era. The art is clearly influenced by visual work from that period including Lynch's Dune. There are multiple endings, and I enjoyed that the best of them still presented a dark and morally clouded set of choices for the main character.The only criticism I have of Primordia is the same criticism I have of similar point-and-click games; many of the inventory combinations and item uses are not intuitive and are occassionally inconsistent. Also, while the side-kick character was a wise choice for an in-game hint system, his personality occassionally feels out of place. FYI: There were also 2 achievements which I believe I met the criteria for but did not recieve. Probably not a bug, but other reviewers have had the same problem.

Posted: December 30, 2016
												This game is absolutely fantastic. I don't think I can do it justice here, but I will try.This game is a work of art. It's very fun and the puzzles are stimulating, but the real treasure is in the dialogue and the world. This game explores the nature of religion, justice, and creation in a post-human, post-apocalyptic world. It's so achingly beautiful. I also literally cried at the end. It's a rare story that can reduce me to tears, but this one did it.Mechanically this game is great as well. The music and the voice acting are wonderful, and the graphics are perfect for the story. The game flows well, and I think it was a good length. The character arc of Horatio was fantastic and satisfying - any longer and I think the game would lose some of the power of its narration.The details are what really make this game. Explore everything. Talk a lot to Crispin. Right-click on everything. Go through all dialogue options. This world is compelling, and beautiful, and utterly desolate. Horatio, the protagonist, is similarly compelling, beautiful, and desolate. If you're looking through the reviews because Primordia's on sale, please just buy it. You will 100% not regret it, I promise.

After seeing some concept art which obviously was not low-res I even wonder whether it would harm the game If it was made in high resolution... The current result is still fine. So, I guess it was not the worst decision anyway.All in all, a very good adventure game. With the current Steam sale price any adventure games lover should give it a try.* The kiosk "puzzle": Art? Seriously, ART? It could easilly be any random word! :)

Posted: December 30, 2016
												If you enjoy dark dystopian sci-fi, beautiful artwork, and a storybook gameplay I highly recommend you try Primordia!As a point-and-click storybook game, Primordia does not dissappoint. It's smart, well-illustrated, and presents a compelling story. The writers took care to build an internally consistent world complete with mythology and believable motives. It's a world I would not be dissappointed to return to in a follow-up title. There is an obvious retro-feel that permeates not only the art style, but also the story and game-mechanic. Primordia's writing reminds me of 1980s robot sci-fi including a few text-based games from that era. The art is clearly influenced by visual work from that period including Lynch's Dune. There are multiple endings, and I enjoyed that the best of them still presented a dark and morally clouded set of choices for the main character.The only criticism I have of Primordia is the same criticism I have of similar point-and-click games; many of the inventory combinations and item uses are not intuitive and are occassionally inconsistent. Also, while the side-kick character was a wise choice for an in-game hint system, his personality occassionally feels out of place. FYI: There were also 2 achievements which I believe I met the criteria for but did not recieve. Probably not a bug, but other reviewers have had the same problem.

Posted: December 30, 2016
												This game is absolutely fantastic. I don't think I can do it justice here, but I will try.This game is a work of art. It's very fun and the puzzles are stimulating, but the real treasure is in the dialogue and the world. This game explores the nature of religion, justice, and creation in a post-human, post-apocalyptic world. It's so achingly beautiful. I also literally cried at the end. It's a rare story that can reduce me to tears, but this one did it.Mechanically this game is great as well. The music and the voice acting are wonderful, and the graphics are perfect for the story. The game flows well, and I think it was a good length. The character arc of Horatio was fantastic and satisfying - any longer and I think the game would lose some of the power of its narration.The details are what really make this game. Explore everything. Talk a lot to Crispin. Right-click on everything. Go through all dialogue options. This world is compelling, and beautiful, and utterly desolate. Horatio, the protagonist, is similarly compelling, beautiful, and desolate. If you're looking through the reviews because Primordia's on sale, please just buy it. You will 100% not regret it, I promise.

Posted: January 13
												Summary : Buy it!Long story:First of all, when you start the game having a 1080p display, the graphics seem extra old, pixelated and just ugly. The reason behind it seems to be the fact that the pixels were drawn by hand. There is a way to "resize" the original 300xsomething resolution and get a nice 1200xsth window without losing quality of detail. (Settings are changed using a separate exe file located in the installation folder)The atmosphere of the game is fantastic. You immerse yourself into a beautifully done post-apocalyptic world filled with dust, junk and characters with their own personalities, thoughts, beliefs and so on. It is a well-thought world based on one of the possible continuations of mankind's history. The game offers multiple completely different endings affected by your interpretation of the world and events around you.The puzzles are fun to solve, you can get hints if you get stuck and there is only a couple of moments when the solution felt not 100% logical to me personally. The interface needs 5-10 minutes to get completely used to, there is a "how to play" option in the menu.I think that purchasing this game is a good idea for point&click experts as well as those new to the genre.

												For those that are fans of Robert Heinlein, Arthur C. Clarke and (most relatable to this game) Isaac Asimov, then this is the game will blow your mind.Admittedly after several hours of frying my mind over the game I resorted to a guide and just enjoyed the excellent voice acting and in depth storytelling.The gaming interface is a little clunky and a highlight option to find out what items are useable would have made things easier, but the over all atmosphere of this game pulled me in. Posted: January 14
												I have played a good number of point and click games. This is what I WANT from a point and click game.  a) Beautiful artwork (why?  cause it is a point and click...you need some bang for your buck. Syberia is a great example of this, though it fails in other regards)b)  Puzzles that are challenging, but intuitive (point-n-clicks RARELY get the 'intuitive part'...I'm looking at you Longest Journey).c) Good voice acting (if they are not text-based) and dialogue.d) Memorable characters (yes Myst...your puzzles were lovely, but there was no one there!!!)e) A cool mechanic (you know, like the time-turning or the pill-popping…ala Fran Bow and others)f) Consequences (if not, choices are meaningless, and point-n-clicks are the perfect medium for giving players choices that matter).Given these personal metrics, I must give this game high marks in all categories.  a) 9/10.  Many folks may disagree. I admit, I was skeptical when I saw screen shots of the game...it looked dated and drab.  But the music and the voice-work mixed with the pixelated brown and reds...somehow it worked beautifully. The style perfectly suited the story.  I thought it was an absolutely beautiful game, with its own unique atmosphere.  Nothing else is quite like it.b) 8/10 – Seriously, this is the first point and click game where I said “well, if I really had these things, this is what I would do” and lo and behold…it was the solution!!!  Plus, there was a fun mix of number-based, logic-based, and text-based puzzles.  The only downside is that I wish there were more!!  And to be fair, not all were challenging…it is a pretty easy game.  But I was never bored or frustrated, so I consider it a win!c) 10/10 – loved every single voice.  And…I mean…they are robots.  And somehow, this game had better voice acting than 90% of the games out there!d) 8/10 – Loved the leads, loved the sides, loved that one lone guy (*sniff*).  More interaction would have allowed better character development for side characters…but it is just a point and click game after all.  The banter is spot-on!e) 6/10 – you get a sidekick who helps you out. Nothing to write home about…although…to be fair…he is a really awesome sidekick personality-wise!! f) Yup.  Consequences and multiple endings.  Woohoo!! (I don’t want to score this part…just wanted to cheer for the effort!)Cons?  Not much.  It is a good time for the price. It is a little short…but it is not “empty”.  Ie, I would rather have a short, full game than a long game of needless filler. If you feel the same, buy it!Hope this helps!

Posted: February 4
Annotation: After having a comprehensive conversation with the developer (which can be found underneath) I decided to change my review entirely. In case you are interested in why this is important to be mentioned, you can find the original review below. But first for the important point:This game has the nicest developer I have ever heard of, in my entire life. Although I couldn't enjoy this awesome game as much as I should have, he was friendly and really supportive. This review was intended to be a negative one, but after I was responded it's really not fair to give him a negativ rating. So yes, this is basically a review for the developer, not for Primordia, but I just have to point that out. If you don't believe me, check the other reviews. He literally responded to every single one, even after more than four years of service. (Go check him out)However, so far for this review, every single line under here is what matters according to my view on the game. Thanks for reading until here. Originally posted by Titanic21:You may hate me for this review, just as a warning.I know that the pixelart style was created on purpose, but a game doesn´t get good by looking like it´s retro or whatever they meant to. I don´t mean that it´s a bad game, please no, Primordia has a rich story, good gameplay and awesome sound design. But also... bad graphics. I am conscious about this game was intended to look like this and I don´t want to say that Primordia requires cinematic graphics. Point and Click games usually don´t look astonishing, that´s not important for the genre. But in this case it´s a little worse. I am almost sorry that I have to complain about this game, which is nice in all other aspects, but the graphics are what makes Primordia really less enjoyable. Eventually it´s NOT helpful for solving puzzles when all objects look the same and you have to find them by slowly moving your cursor all over the screen, as if this was a hidden-object-game. It´s hard to even recognize the textures and by looking closer you´ll get more confused than you already are. I bought this because I like point ´n click games a lot, and I have to admit that Primordia looked a lot better in the trailer. I wish the developers would have designed this more like Daedalic would have done, instead of Lucas Arts´ way, so that I could enjoy the game. The harder I try, the more I see how pointless it is. Playing such an awesome game is exhausting if you can´t clearly detect important elements. To not repeat me I will close this review now, if you read closely you should already have understood what I was saying. I  do seriously hope that you´ll have different experiences while playing Primordia.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												Primordia is, at it's core, a nostalgic trip to the old days of the Point-and-Click Adventure genre of gaming that at this day and age has almost been completely forgotten and lost.  And what a welcome blast from the past it is indeed.  Following the travels and trials of Horatio and Crispin, this game tells an amazing story with all the conventions of the P&C genre.  But it's not QUITE to same as the games of old, such as King's Quest, or Broken Sword.For starters, the game tells you outright that you cannot die, or can you take an action that renders the game "unwinnable", a flaw that made many of the classic staples of point-and-click, like King's Quest 5, atrocities of game design.  The locales don't require meticulous pixel hunts to find that one item you need in order to progress.  Travelling the maps is expidited by a fast-travel system that easily lets you jump from place to place.  Combining items is no longer a nonsensical MacGuyver mish-mash of parts, it's all explained and makes perfect sense.  No longer do you need a notebook to take down vital information, a handy item in-game records all the most relevant information for you, and your helper will at times offer a light nudge towards the next possible objective.And that's just the mechanics.  The game's art and sound, two of the major foundations of point-and-click, which lives and thrives (or fails and dies) off it's atmosphere, are in full force.  The discoloration of the game's settings isn't just to be "realistic", it's a compliment to the setting and aesthetic.  And the music is highly atmospheric.  From the haunting melody of the game's menu theme "Primordia" to the tune of "The City of Glass and Light", the music compliments the setting as much as the color palette.  The characters are all fully voiced, and the voice work is clean and quality, with voices befitting each character and role.Of course, Primordia isn't perfect.  For starters, the biggest and possibly most glaring flaw, is just how SHORT the game is.  Even if the puzzles make you spend extra time (and at first, they will), you'll likely only wind up spending 5-7 hours on this game.  It's basically over before it seems to really begin.  While it follows the classic story-telling formula, the climax of the story seems to be on you before you know it.  A point in the game that feels like the 50% is more like the 75% mark instead.  And before you know it, you're already at the final scene.  Even with multiple endings (which can be achieved by just reloading and making a different choice) the game feels painfully short-lived.  You'll be left wanting to hear and see more.The music, while perfectly fitting the mood, never seems to stick with the player much.  I couldn't tell you a moment in the game and point out the music for it, besides the music at the main menu.  Which isn't to say the music is bad, because it's not.  But it's not catchy much.  Or very present.  The music mostly serves as a background to the game, ambience.  And it does it's part amazingly well.  I just wish that perhaps the music felt a bit more powerful at certain scenes.  Speaking of sound, the voice-acting and sound effects are a bit off as well.  Some scenes would have effects, like gunshots, with NO sound accompanying them, which removed something important to the scene.  And the voice actors themselves, while very good, still felt a bit rough.  Horatio's voice actor in particular, either does a stellar job, or seems a bit too stoic when you'd think a situation would call for a more forceful, emotional or venomous delivery.Overall though, Primordia definitely feels like it was a game that SHOULD have existed back in the Golden Age of the adventure genre of PC gaming.  It feels like a game that I missed from my childhood and I'm just getting to sit down and enjoy it now for the first time in years, and it's not even that old!  But it takes me back to that time in gaming that I've almost forgotten and reminded me of what games I use to partake of, and that's a feeling I can't being to say how much I enjoy.  If you are a person who enjoys the point-and-click genre, grew up in that era, or want a relaxing, easy-paced game that can still deliver a great story, Primordia is worth every possible virtual cent you pay for it.

Posted: December 17, 2013
												Let me just say, I adore this game. As someone who enjoys point-and-click adventure games as well as cyberpunk themes, this was a match made in heaven.The story revolves around Horatio and Crispin, two robots who live in a wrecked ship. Horatio is a believer in Humanism, that humans are the creators, which is a frowned upon idea in the world the live in. They live far away from the city, isolated, until their power supply is stolen and they are forced to go to Metropol. As they search they discover the corrupt system that the city is operating under and Horatio's past. The characters themselves were enough to keep me playing. I enjoyed each one's own personality, their dialog, their story, it was all well done. The art style very well sets the tone for Primordia and was pleasing to look at while playing. The story was actually surprisingly well done and with multiple endings it just increases the replay value as well as my interests. It was challenging enough to where I felt incredibly accomplished once I finished it, but easy enough to where I didn't rage quite and ignore it for days. I was easily absorbed into Primordia's world and it's certainly a game I will replay more than once (and already have).Overall, worth the money and the time if you enjoy this genre. A must have.

Posted: July 18, 2014
												This game surprised me. I went in expecting another tedious point-n-click, but was quickly sucked into the world that is Primoridia. You play a robot named Horatio that is on a quest for the rather simple goal of finding his home's battery. What ensues is a storyline that unveils a history and lore rooted in a mixture of "God and his creation", aiming forward with questions of freewill and the role of the State within a society. All the while, Horatio simply wants his power core. A brilliant, rich and enticing game. It asks more questions that it answers, while playing with your imagination and leaves you wanting more from this universe. All in all, if you're looking for a game that challenges your logic and problem-solving skills, while experiencing a well-developed world and excellent cast of characters, look no further.

												Despite a few minor shortcomings, Primordia is a true gem, a deceptively simple cyber-punk thriller that gradually blossoms into a dystopian epic adventure with rich lore that dares to pose profound philosophical questions. In merely 8-9 hours, the player follows Horatio and Crispin in an unforgettable journey of thought and emotion, which combines the unfolding of a gripping tale with clever puzzles and addictive old-school adventure game gameplay.Full Review: http://adventureadvocate.gr/gamereviews/item/primordia

Posted: February 16, 2015
												A beautifully realized indie adventure game with alternative paths and multiple endings, Primordia is one of the best point-and-click gems you've never heard of. Set in a far-future dystopian setting, robots struggle to make sense of a world where humans, their creators, no longer exist. As Horatio, a robot seeking to repair what has broken or fallen into disuse, you will explore the landscape of the desolate world and explore one of the few remaining cities with his faithful and sarcastic sidekick Crispin. The voice-work is excellent, as are the music and visuals. Now with the 2.0 release, I'm looking forward to playing it again and taking a different path.

Posted: July 21, 2016
												I held of on buying this game for a very long time due to how minimal it seemed, but after playing it I wished I hadn't done so.  This game is as close to flawless as an adventure game can ever be.  It has the best writing and the best soundtrack of any video game I've played and has a surprisingly deep setting and lore to it, which is impressive considering the small size of the game world.  With just a few locations, it creates a realistic world that had me immersed for hours.The story and atmosphere of the game did a remarkable job of drawing me in and building tension, but where I believe the game stands out the most is in its setting.  The game takes place in a future in which life has long been extinct and Man has become a mythical deity worshipped by the remaining robots that now wander the lifeless desert that covers the earth, or even dismissed altogether as nothing more than legend.  Glass and light have become precious resources and what little remains of human invention is constantly scrapped to build new robots.  This is the kind of creativity that is lacking in most adventure games, and the subtlety with which it was presented was refreshing.It was surprising to see a post-apocalyptic setting in which humans take only a background role and the nature of the world before is long forgotten.  Rather than barrage the player with the history of the world, Primordia puts the story and gameplay first while allowing players to discover the lore on their own, avoiding many (though not quite all) of the tropes that plague post-apocalyptic, dystopian, and robotic science fiction settings.The game takes itself seriously and the comic relief exists for the amusement of the characters rather than that of the player, which is a skillful way of keeping the story believable, though Crispin's lines did make me cringe in more than a few points.  The primary cause of the chaotic dystopia is the degradation and corruption of the robots' programming, which becomes increasingly apparent as more of them are encountered.  All of the robots from the days of the humans are dead, insane, or rebuilt to the point of having no memories of the previous era, and the world inhabited by the rusting automotons that remain of civilization is chaotic, unpredictable, and bleak.  The dramatic irony of many characters' situations as well as the limited color palette contribute a depressing and hopeless tone that makes this an especially memorable experience.Primordia is an essential contribution to the adventure genre of computer games, and one that I will gladly recommend to anyone who has an interest in interactive stories.  If you are considering getting Primordia, then please do yourself a favor and don't make the mistake I made of waiting for several years before buying it.

Posted: March 13, 2016
												This game is beauty incarnate. It uses the point-and-click adventure format masterfully, and delivers an incredible experience. Unlike some other games (Blackwell Epiphany, cough-cough xD), you always feel like you have agency, and the number of alternate endings only add to this feel. The puzzles are fair, and the world vast and interesting.As someone who grew up on Lem's Cyberiad, for me, robots inhabiting a post-mankind world was a must buy... but what really managed to awe me was how incredibly well they were executed. No throw-away characters and no bad cliches in this game.If you like Asimov or Lem, robots, and adventure games, get this. It's one of the top titles of the genre at the moment, surpassing even many of the big old titles by LucasArts in the golden days.

Posted: January 13, 2016
												A very good point n click about robots in a post-human world that oozes atmosphere. Think Fallout/Wasteland + Machinarium with more voice acting (starring Logan Cunningham of Bastion fame!) Posted: January 14, 2016
												Primordia is not what it first appears. It's description is: "What happened to the Humans", but that isn't what the game is about. I thought this would be an Adeptus Mechanicus themed Adventure game with a Sam and Max buddyish element, but was actually wrong.Instead, this is a game about logic, law, and a divide between liberty and community. The main characters are both charming and the other characters all have little quirks that ensures there is no "that guy" of the game. The puzzles are good without ever being too challenging and the story is tightly knit, with only about 10-11 locations and about 15 characters in the entire game. It's concise without any red herrings. Actually, because the game is so tightly knit, some important secrets are left out in plain sight, which makes it interesting to replay. What I also like about the puzzles in this game are that there's dialouge if the game understands what you were trying to do with a puzzle, but you were using the wrong piece and there's multiple ways to solve several of the puzzles. In fact, the biggest and longest puzzle of the game can literally be bypassed from the moment you enter the second act. My only complaint with the game would be the antagonist. The antagonist has a trait that they can "never lie" but then you manage to catch them in lies several times and when confronted with this, the antagonist says "no player, you must be mistaken because I am not". In a game where the entire second act is about logic, it just seems silly. Additionally, my other problem with the antagonist is that at one point the antagonist just says "I know you have a lot of questions about the world and history of this game world, so let me answer all of them for you". However, that small gripe aside, this game had me engaged and immersed the whole time, trying to figure out its secrets and lore (until the minute that it got bored and laid out its cards on the table).

												Wow, what can I say.  As of writing this, Primordia is about 95% positive, and should probably be 99%.  Great game, pulled me right in and stayed up 'till 4am finishing in one sitting.  Strong contentender for my favorite game.  I will say, take your time toward the end, there are some important things you can miss right after the explosion.  That's not a spoiler, but you can REALLY easily miss two very important things if you are not careful, it's worth looking at a walkthrough if you don't find them.  If you have not played this one, do yourself a favor and just do it.  It took me a long time try it because I was kind of on the fence about whether to play a "point & click".  Now, it makes me look at several other games and wonder if they would be better in this format.  No offense to the original Deus Ex, I love that game, but that game would be killer in this format with it's great story & characters.  Primordia makes me want to write the story for a P&C game, and I think I will give it a try!!

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												TL;DR: If you love noir and/or sci-fi, get this on sale and play with a walkthrough, because it's not a super-fun game, but it's an awesome experience!A very classic-feeling adventure game with a perfect blend of science fiction and noir - and not the watered-down versions you might be used to, I mean think classics, the genre-defining stuff people still remember from 50+ years ago. As a fan of both, I was very satisfied. It's a smart story excellently told with top-notch writing and art. Kudos to the devs for having the game run in super-low resolution - no accidental ruining of the retro feel by hi-res glows or particle effects. You want retro? This is retro. The art direction is consistent right down to the screen resolution.As a game... not so much. See, it's an adventure game, and that means exactly what you think it means. Personally, I bought it for half-off and after the first 40 minutes or so I opened up a guide - so much more enjoyable! The writing is witty, the world-building is amazing, the story unfolds with perfect timing... why be bogged down with "find the hidden active zone in the dozen screens you have access to" or "use X on Y in order to use X, Y, and Z together, no other combination works"? Those games are dumb. When you actually have all the items and clues the puzzles are usually not stupid, but you never really know if you do - the fundamental failing of adventure games. Don't put yourself through that just to get at the good stuff. Keep a walkthrough open and peek at it any time you're starting to get the slightest doubt on how to proceed.I am not the kind of person who usually goes into games for storytelling, but I am a sucker for sci-fi and an even bigger sucker for noir, so this was totally worth it. If I'd known how good a time I would have I might have even paid full price! If any of what I wrote sounded interesting and you have the time to kill, it's definitely worth at least the price of a movie ticket.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Primordia is a sci-fi, futuristic, post-apocalyptic story where you play as a robot named Horatio. In the world of Primordia robots run the planet; "Man" is but long forgotten and a thing only of legend. The puzzles are decently hard but not overbearing. Some puzzles actually have multiple solutions and the game has multiple endings. There is a built in hint system that you have the option of using. The hints gently nudge you in the correct direction but do not give obvious answers. I liked how the story pokes fun/satirizes modern day society and its views on religion without making it overly obvious. It was done subtley and in good taste. The story is just really well done; it is one of my favorites and certainly memorable. Primordia isn't just a well designed game; it is also beautiful, sad, and poetic. Overall, definitely another great title from Wadjet Eye. Side note - There is an option to turn on commentary from the writers. I highly recommend turning on the commentary if you are enjoying the game - it provides a ton of context and for me made the experience even more so enjoyable.9.5/10Please upvote this review if you found it useful :)

It takes place in a post apocalpytic world where humans have gone extinct. The main character is an android named Horatio who undergoes a quest that leads him to discovering his origins and why the world ultimately ended.It's a nice enough game in general, and it's engine reminds me quite a lot of Scumm. Of course it's not a particularly difficult game, and without prior interest in the genre it will just collect dust on your harddrive.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												I liked it a lot. It's dark and grim. It's about "Horatio Nullbuilt", a somewhat stoic and secretive humanoid robot living alone in some long-stranded organic-looking airship in the middle of some barren brown desert. Humans are long gone, only machines remain, some worship them - or their legacy - in a secluded and lonesome manner as Horatio does. He has a self-built low-grade flying companion robot, "Crispin Horatiobuilt", who is an obvious sidekick, who keeps refering to himself as that and who is supposed to be a constant contrast to his builder for he is not as nearly withdrawn as him but more humorous, even on a meta-like level for example when he comments your futile efforts to do the same thing over and over and expecting different results.There are more interesting characters to see. All kinds of machines who inhabit the few remaining places in the world. Be it a bomb from some long-past war that never detonated and which is worshipped for it is a creation of man, the remains of colossal titan robots buried deep within the desert or old human cities maintained by robots just enough not to collapse totally.Primorida is a middle-scaled adventure for what I can tell. It has an interesting story, great characters, powerful voice acting (every character is voiced - and those robots who cannot talk bleep around in their own manner) and a significant amount of puzzling too. If I remember right I had to look up a walkthrough a few times, though I guess I was just blind on one eye for the solutions seemed reasonable afterwards. There are several endings, they all seem fitting and interesting in their way, and while the decision which you will see is made very lately in the game it is still somewhat relevant what you do mid-game. There is a significant amount of lore background. You will meet characters who share their stories and views on the world. You will learn more about them, their motivations and failures. There is a robot society that kinda imitates human society. It has it's own leadership and entities. However barely anything about is perfect. It is in demise, and Horatio is trying to find his way through. He is connected to the world around him more than he admits, and getting to know him better was done very well I think, from robots remembering him to data logs hidden within the places he visits. The art is nice, there are some great dark or soothing music tunes, everything seemed crafted together well and I thought I was satisfied with all aspects of the game even though it has been a long while since I've played it. Definitely the best adventure from Wadjet Eye Games I've played thus far.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Primordia is an attempt at a weighty story that somewhat misses its mark in execution.  As in all adventure games, things start innocently (loosely applied) enough as a giant robot looking like the mobile version of HAL crossed with a lobster (I know, right?) invades your home on a derelict ship and steals your power core.  You, Horatio, from a long line of previous Horatios, must now find a way to retrieve it.  It should be mentioned that everyone in this game, including you, is a robot, and as you begin to explore the world and meet its denizens, you'll find yourself wrapped in a robot existentialist's wetware runtime environment, rolling around in what amounts to be the robotic version of a Kafka story... okay, maybe not that weighty.  There's just something about the ending (of which there are many) that just never seems satisfying, even if you take all the steps to do the 'good' one.  That being said, Primordia still manages to tell its story with care and it's delivered in perfectly-bleak dialogue for a perfectly-bleak world.Technically, the game suffers a little bit from a few questionable design decisions.  Being (I assume) an homage to the point 'n' click (PNC) games of yesteryear, the developer insisted on a low-res, 2D game - which is great - but instead of doing what most modern games do which is make a hi-res game look low-res, this game is actually 800x600.  This isn't really that big a deal until you notice that often the character sprites don't 'belong' to the scene.  In classic adventure games, different sprites were created depending on where the character is supposed to be standing; in Primordia, the technique used instead is simply scaling down the larger sprite with the end result being a much crisper sprite on a purposely-blocky background.  Not a dealbreaker, but it can be a little bit distracting.Other design decisions that were made are quite inexcusable in a modern PNC game.  Despite the genre being declared 'dead' for years, the truth is that the genre has thrived (loosely applied) throughout the decades and made many advances, all of which are ignored by Primordia.  For instance, in most modern PNCs, there's a hotspot-highlight button to speed along play; Primordia does not have that.  In most modern PNCs, you can usually double-click an exit to skip the slow plod of the character walking offscreen; Primordia does not have that.  To be fair, it -does- have a map system for quick travel.Finally, there is what is known as adventure-game-logic and Primordia is rife with it.  If you're unfamiliar with the term, it is a criticism of classic adventure game puzzle solutions and how they often make little logical sense.  For example, if you needed to sharpen a pencil, logic would dictate you find a pencil sharpener, but older adventure games were known for instead making you combine a stick with a piece of glass and some tape in order to whittle the pencil... while you stand in front of a pencil sharpener.  While the puzzles in Primordia aren't quite so asinine, two extremely dense puzzles spring to mind that are just bad ideas.  Like older adventure games, you could totally sit there and work it out and feel that ego boost, but I find it hard to believe that most players won't be looking for a walkthrough when they encounter them.  That being said, most of the game is paced out well so long as you can get your head into that mindframe of the 90s and just tough it out.All in all, Primordia is an accomplished title and a lot of love went into it, especially in the art department.  For a game entirely populated by artificial beings, there is a sort of haunting organic decay that pierces almost every piece of art in the game.  Similarly, the voice direction is quite good and despite Crispin - your sidekick floaty robot buddy - sounding a hell of a lot like Otacon from Metal Gear Solid (it doesn't fit, believe me), every one of the actors gets what the director is trying to accomplish and paints a beautiful, if desolate, piece of work.By all accounts, I did not enjoy (but did not dislike) Primordia particularly because I found a lot of the puzzles to be purposely obtuse and the story was not one that resonated with me.  However, that does not make this a bad game and so I cannot possibly give it a thumbs down.  For some people, the story is a mindblowing, harrowing look at the nature of existence, life, its foundations, and its possible future.  It is a fascinating perspective, to be sure, but I was left unsatisfied.Thus, if you're looking for a new PNC game, there's no reason to steer clear from this one.  What I present above are not detractions, but warnings.  PNC veterans will not bat an eye at anything that goes on in this game, but fans of modern PNC games might find a lot of things in Primordia to be frustrating.  Stick with it and it mostly rewards you - just remember that it's more about the journey than the destination in this one.

												I recommend this game. However I have to point it isn't going to be the best adventure you have ever played. I really liked how decisions mattered and it's nice to see an adventure willing to take risks and giving more than one solution for most puzzles. The writer namedrops loads of great novels and other games and stories as inspirations that helped shape this game, which only makes it the more sad that this game is only "not bad." Not bad is still recommended in my book.

												This was an interesting game. Don't be fooled by the endings you think you see. Somehow, I managed to mess up the game so badly that I only got sad endings. These are the endings that no one talks about. The endings where the main character's friends are all dead, and he goes back to his ship, and reprograms himself to forget about what happened at the city. The ending when he has nothing left to live for.Yet, I have seen other playthroughs where he manages to save his friends, and the ending is full of hope. It all depends on you. Will you save your friends? Will you join the AI who ruined your life? It is all your choice.and in the end, what does it mean to be human?

												It was interesting and kept me through the whole thing, though there were a few points I couldn't figure out the creators 'logic'. That's not uncommon though, as what is obvious to it's creator may be extremely obscure at time to others. The graphics looked pixelated, but even giving it some leeway for being fullscreen, they were still a bit too pixelated for my preferences. There seemed to be no antialiasing at all. Sometimes the things you have to find, despite having no clue they are supposed to exist, are small objects, blend in very well with the clutter and trash, or are in dark areas and not really visible.  This isn't exactly an uncommon theme with these types of adventure games. Still, I rather enjoyed it, and hope the author takes the criticisms to heart and makes an even better game next time. I'm going to have to give it a yes.

content:
Posted: February 20
												Primordia centers on the travails of two robots, Horatio and Crispen, who live in what is eventually revealed to be a warship on the edge of the ruins of a great city, Metropol. Their wasteland idyll is broken when another robot appears and steals the pair's power core. As robots, they require power, and embark upon a journey in a wasteland that reflects the splendour of a now dead world. Historically, I am not a fan of point-and-click adventure games.  But this game may have changed that. While I did occassionally cheat and look for solutions online, the tale of our two robots drew me in like the scent of a pitcher plant draws in flies. Upon reflection, the story reminds me of something that would have been published in Metal Hurlant three or more decades ago (minus the gratutious sex). The game makes explicit, though with subtle insertion, reference to other  speculative fiction masterpieces from multiple media. Fallout, Half-Life and A Canticle for Liebowitz being the ones I could clearly identify. Furthermore, the development team, usually the writer, provide liner notes revealing the design decisions they made in making this compelling tale. As someone interested in the division of labor in video game production, this was fascinating in its own right. If you like dystopian or melancholoy worldbuilding, this game is for you.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												This game is a point and click adventure set in a post-apocalpytic world where all humans are (presumably) dead.  Although I haven't really read books or played other games on this topic, I think it does a pretty good take on the setting, enough so to spark some creative interest of my own.  The characters and full-game voicework are for the most part fairly well done but dialogue kind of falls flat in a few places, mostly because of the script writing and not because of the voice actors.  The story is fairly cohesive and events therein are weighty and interesting, but in a few places I feel like the scenes were not given -enough- weight.  This is especially true of all the alternate endings and post-game cinematics, which although included to give the player some logical options, needed a bit more fleshing out.  It is also interesting to point out, it is impossible to game over although some decisions can change your endings.The visual aesthetic of the game is quite nice, as is the music.  While pleasant to listen to and not annoying in any way, none of the tunes were especially catchy or easily memorable, and in a few of the dramatic scenes a stronger musical touch would have gone a long way.  Sound effects are unfortunately fairly weak, lacking thematic when operating devices and having little oomph when explosions occur, and in some places the game seems bugged and plays no sound effect at all.  The voice work has a nice robotic emulation added, although some characters seem to exhibit multiple variances in recording quality or style that doesn't seem to be a character quirk.Performance-wise the game runs fine.  Although it resizes itself and forces fullscreen (thus making dual-monitor setups a little wonky), the resolution is not a complaint.  I never had pathing issues or pixel-hunts (just me being blind).  The game interface is functional and unobtrusive, as well as autosaving.  There are some included commentaries as well in the options menu.All in all, I really did enjoy the game despite some of its flaws.  Its not very expensive, and it's about 7 hours of gameplay for one playthrough, with low replayability.  The setting is done very nicely and the story is good, what's there to complain about is mostly some rough edges and needed spitshining.  It doesn't ruin the game at all.  I'd say pick it up.
