Posted: June 12, 2015
												I am a huge fan of Point and Click games, from the DOTT and Monkey Island games. I am a huge fan of Wadjet Eye games and I usually buy all of their creations. So like all of the games I played through I'm going to review it in PROs and CONs. Or you can of course read the Verdict at the end.PROs: Beautiful pixel art graphics Incredibly immersive  Awesome storyline Really good and unique Jokes especially if you're a computer geek You have a floating companion A lot of content to explore and scenes to unlock Multiple choices to solve puzzles Multiple endings (you should play all of them) Really really awesome ambient and musicb]CONs:[/b] Too short Should be longer  Really too short Some parts of the game should be more explorable WE NEED MORE BACKSTORYVerdictIt's an incredibly beautiful game, with beautiful music and funny jokes. I really hope for a sequel or anything happening in the future. It has multiple choices of how to solve a puzzle, which is somewhat revolutionizing, since in the early games there was only one way to finish the game. Now I really want to replay some of the scenes because of different interactions. The one and only CON that I could think of is, that it's simply too short. I finished it in less than 20 hrs and after it I felt sad that it already ended. It had a lot of fun and interesting characters. Another awesome job you did there Wadjet Eye!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												A mysterious past is slowly unveiled in a post-apocalyptic art-noveau cyberpunk world.If you like robots, themes of AI, and/or adventure games - especially classic ones - this game is for you.  The game follows the pretty standard adventure mechanic - click on things to make things happen - sometimes click on things with things from your inventory, or mix things in your inventory together until they become clickable on other things.  Take notes.  (Most of which actually happens for you with the in-game "data-pad".)  Solve puzzles with said notes.  The game runs at 640x400 resolution - which can be off-putting to some, but really lends to the retro-adventure feel of the game, and I've come to love it.  (On my 1080p tv, it won't actually fill up the whole screen, but it doesn't really bother me.)  That said - I highly recommend going into the options menu and chosing the "DX" display mode as opposed to D3D if it works for you - the sprites mesh with the backgrounds much better this way in my opinion.  DOS nostalgia!What really shines in Primordia is the story - and the art.  They come together to create a fascinating atmosphere that makes me want to revisit the game again and again - and the developer commentary is great on a second or third playthrough.  The excellent voice acting and seven or so potential endings don't hurt, either.  (The narrator from Bastion plays the main character - and the sidekick that follows you through the game is entertaining at every turn.)  The music and sound mesh well with the art to create an engrossing atmosphere - despite the retro low-res graphics.  There aren't many puzzles in the "puzzle game" sense - but there is plenty of puzzling to be done in the game in terms of figuring out how things fit together, what things mean, and what the significance of certain items or pieces of information may be.  The story is mostly linear, but there are a few opportunities to take different approaches to solve situations - especially near the end.  Observation and careful contemplation are rewarded.The setting is in the distant future in a post-human world - no organic life is to be found anywhere - even the bugs and little things swimming in the sewers are machines - but make no mistake, they have lives and thoughts of their own, and are no less interesting than any human character.  And for the robot fan, there are references to other robots from both popular and obscure culture everywhere - along with a videogame reference or two.  MST3K, Short Circuit, Metropolis, and Fallout - just to name a few.I would highly recommend this game to any fan of classic graphic adventures, narrative-driven games, or robots.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												Great art, engaging story. However, the game has a critical flaw that permeates the entire experience: discovering how to progress is less an exercise in logic and more an exercise in clicking and walking the world. Many of the components of each puzzle are only tangentially related, oftentimes only in the most esoteric ways. Progression is further  hindered by the game's lack of robust programming. Sometimes you will try something that should work, only to find out that you were supposed to perform that action through slightly different mechanisms. The game also does not handle choices well. Now, there aren't many story-altering choices to make in this game, but the creators should have given the player more indications of what the effects of their actions would be, as well as more indication that certain paths could have been taken. I felt cheated out of the ending I would have chosen because of the problem I mentioned above. I clicked on something, nothing happened, and I went on my way, not realizing that I could have performed the intended action. This changed the ultimate ending.Still very much recommended, but don't be ashamed to open up a guidebook if you get stuck.Edit: Also, the save system was bad. They could have easily done it better.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												If story is more important for you in a game than mechanics or visuals than you will enjoy Primordia as it is a decently written story.> Great game lore / interesting setting> Great plot and semi twist if you don't see it coming, I enjoyed the little seeds throughout the game like the ship being named "UNIIC"  (VGER anyone?).If the writer reads this not that I minded the ending but I think the twist would have had even more punch if Horus had followed through with his mission instead of Metromind carrying it out, big bad being the big bad is not as fun of a twist as the good guy was the bad guy. Would have made the final choice more interesting and a more interesting realization for the player "I'm a humanist trying to save humanity but I killed them?", my two cents as a wannabe writer, was still good though> Main character deals with interesting themes, and can choose different paths, "Progress needs transformation needs art needs freedom" reminded me of 'what can change the nature of a man' from Planescape: Torment... was interesting to think about it, as were the logical arguments of the robots> Sidekick character is more funny and likeable than most comedic relief companion characters, reminded me a lot of Morte from Planescape:Torment while still being unique and memorable as his own character  I felt a great deal of loss after he died, almost found myself getting angry like the main character and strongly felt his absense in the scenes following his death, great immersion!Mild Cons:> Puzzles were okay, not overly hard or easy. I enjoyed the logic puzzles more so than go search a map for random item (I could see others minding those quests less), the wingman quest though had me chuckle> Game is short, 9 hrs for me with frequent pauses leaving the game running while I took breaks> Graphics are reto pixels but not bad if you zoom out, took my eyes a bit to adjust in the beginningFor me money well spent, memorable story.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												+++ Puzzles that make realistic sense, well-integrated into the story, and with multiple ways to solve them.+++ Solid script, greatly blending comedy and drama.+++ Rich and palpable world, friendly to immersion.--- Hand-drawn vistas difficult to appreciate due to the game's old-school extra-low resolution.Primordia is a game that almost plays itself.  The sort of puzzle-adventure where you become engrossed into the world, and lose track of time.  Its strongest point by far is how its puzzles blend in seamlessly with the world story, and thus the solutions feel natural and well thought out.  Without doubt, this is an extremely high-quality game.

number of helpful: 20 of 41 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												Primordia is a point and click game that has beautiful artwork and immersive music. The story is enjoyable and I encountered zero bugs. The characters are well-developed and the occasional humor is pretty funny. Sounds awesome, right? Well, there's just one problem: I didn't have fun. As I played I felt more annoyed by the puzzles than I felt happy that I completed them. Because as soon as you fix a problem, PLOP new thing for you to fix! At first, Crispin's (your comedic companion) hints helped but when you get farther he seems to just tell you what you already know. The items you must obtain are typically in places that you wouldn't expect, and the hitboxes for them are typically small. This game just drives you to the point where you try to use every item on every object, even if it doesn't make sense, to see if that will work. I found myself sitting there trying to combine my crowbar with my memory pouch. What will that do? Nothing. But I HAD to try it because I've done everything else. And then it turns out all you had to do was something simple but there was no way you could have known about it. This game has so many amazing qualities; I wanted to like it so bad. But I just couldn't. It's just not fun. Overall, I just found this game more frustrating than satisfying. If you've got the ten bucks and you LOVE point and click puzzle adventures, go for it. You might like it. But for the average gamer, I cannot recommend this game.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												I'm sorry to say that I was rather disappointed with this game. I think the trailer made me expect too much from it (what else is new). And the first half of the game itself made me expect too much from the second half. I can't really say how without spoiling, unfortunately. Let's just say that I expected some pretty grand moments that the game never even came close to delivering. But I would still recommend this game, as parts of the story are pretty interesting and some of the puzzles and conversations are cool.I do have to talk about Crispin though. It feels like they tried to make a Wheatley-esque character who follows you everywhere, and is kind of annoying but also endearing and adorable. Unfortunately they made Crispin too much of a smartass, so he comes off as not very endearing, not even remotely adorable, but still quite annoying. His lines also get very tiresome, as they are often just lame puns and jokes, and he doesn't have a very large number of them. And aside from scripted scenes, his comedic presence didn't change in response to the increasingly minatory plot, which often ruined the tone.Lastly, the voice-acting generally isn't very good. The villain probably has the best voice-acting. The voices themselves? Very good, well-chosen, well-suited to their characters. But the acting itself wasn't very good. It's fairly boring and I got tired of listening to everyone speak pretty quickly. Perhaps this was intentional because they were robots, but you can make someone sound robotic without sacrificing solid, emotive acting (case in point: Portal).

Posted: February 16, 2014
												Bottom line: I can recommend this game to fans of the genre, however it is not without it's flaws. It will probably be a rewarding experience if you are willing to approach it charitably. However, there are better games of this kind to play first (Gemini Rue, the Blackwell series and so on).Pros: A very well crafted and engaging universe, with it's own history and mythology. Some excellent puzzle design in parts. A haunting atmosphere facilitated by a decent soundtrack (probably inspired by Vangelis' Blade Runner music). Fans of Beneath a Steel Sky will find much to like here.Cons: Impossible to enjoy without a walkthrough on hand to get over the occasional obtuse puzzle solution. Could have done with more blind testing to deal with this, or a more robust hint system. Some of the voice acting feels a little innappropriate in tone - the sidekick character in particular.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												Primordia is a game about robots.  Unlike Machinarium, it is a very dark and gritty setting.  While that fits the game very well, it makes the artwork quite dull and dreary, amplified by the very low resolution the game runs at.  The story, however, makes good use of the setting and is well-written and even includes multiple endings, but that unfortunately is the extent of the the game that I enjoyed.Primordia is the best example I have run into of a modern adventure game succumbing to the classic adventure game failing of very confusing and obtuse puzzles.  If you don't already need a guide to complete the story, and you probably will, trying to complete the optional achievements is even worse, essentially necessitating the use of a guide.It's hard for me to recommend Primordia when there's so many better adventure games to choose from.

number of helpful: 11 of 27 people (41%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												First the good: Nice world, nice graphics, reasonable story, adequate voice acting.Now the bad: Arbitrary puzzles, extemely linear, except for the magic points you should save to redo different "paths" for the achievements, terrible obvious boring ending, unskippable credit sequence that doesn't even respect alt-F4, and worst of all it just not fun.Constructive advice to the devs: Don't make your hint bot refuse to give hints, especially in a snarky tone. Make your puzzles actually make sense. Tell the player when the path of a mostly linear game is going to diverge. Better yet, auto-save right before that divergence. Allow the player to be the hero at the end. Choosing "I'll never join you!" should not end with a crap series of still screens and the player losing to the big bad.Constructive advice to people who play it: Use a walkthrough. The first part is pretty decent but the city is just silly and arbitrary. And you'll never get the achievements without a walkthrough, unless you click everything always forever in the right order (including not talking to someone when you first meet them!).

number of helpful: 5 of 17 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												I would really like to recommend this game but I simply can't.  Despite the unique story, amazing voice acting, and fun universe it all took a back seat to the puzzle aspect of the game.I'm no stranger to adventure games.  I've always been a fan of these types of games but Primordia simply doesn't do it for me.  I found the puzzles to be frustrating and counter intuitive.Part way through the game I ran into a game breaking bug that caused it to be impossible to continue without a guide.  After an hour of rubbing things on other things and clicking on every pixel I did the unthinkable and went to a guide only to find out I've run into a somewhat common glitch.  On this Steam forum I see a post from one of the writers/designers for the game say "Sigh. If we ever do another patch, I'll make sure it gets fixed."  This is my ulitmate woe with the indy developer.  I pay for the game and I would hope that known bugs would be fixed.  I don't like to hear "IF we ever do another patch."  A bug in an adventure game isn't like most other games.  You don't always know there is a problem.  You just keep trying to solve the puzzle till you give up or turn to a guide.  For me that ruined half the experience.  Now every time I get stuck I wonder if I'm wasting my time because of another bug or did I forget to pick up a cup of coffee three screens back.TLDR:  If you want the game then get it for the story and the art and not the puzzles.

number of helpful: 6 of 24 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												Overall this is a sad case of a game with brilliant elements but too many faults to make it an enjoyable experience. It has the best sense of humour of just about any game I have played. The story is good, though some of the elements don't fit together.The problems are:  1/ the graphics are terrible. Yes, they have a cute, arty style but they are ridiculously low resolution. 2/ The mechanics are clunky, with slow menus and too much time watching pixellated figures crossing the screen painfully slowly. 3/ Some of the puzzles are good, but a lot of the time I had to use a walkthrough not because a puzzle was difficult but because the game is inconsistent. Most exits are identified by mousing over, but some are only identified if you move the character to the edge of the screen. There is a system of storing info useful for solving puzzles but some of the info stored is irrelevant and some vital info is not stored. To combine items in inventory you pick up A and mouse it over B. You get a message telling you that's a dumb idea, but it turns out you need to pick up B and mouse it over A.

number of helpful: 8 of 29 people (28%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Primordia is a point-and-click adventure game with a "classic" look. The story is set in a sci-fi world, where all humans have died and only robots remain. Even though the game has an interesting setting, the story was kinda dull.Graphics-wise the game looks like the classic point-and-click adventures of the 90's. The world looked interesting with its post-apocalyptic look, but often the graphics were quite low-res, which is unfortunate. Music was pretty nice although I didn't pay much attention to it. However, I thought the voice acting was pretty bad even though most reviews online say it's great. The voices didn't seem to fit the characters, which made me dislike some of them. Especially the voice of the droid companion was kinda annoying.The puzzles were kinda hard, because they weren't very logical and sometimes required you to backtrack to a previous area to get an item that wasn't available there before. It would have been fine, if you had to use a certain item to get that other item i.e. the item was there, but you couldn't get it yet. The "appearance" of the needed item wasn't indicated in any way. So basically the puzzle design was quite bad.Overall it's an average point-and-click adventure that suffers from bad puzzle design and a dull story.

												Great ambience, amazing soundtrack ( as a musician myself i am astonished by it, thank you Victor) and one of the best game narratives that i ever played.The philosophical question about humans and robots relantionship is so well done that resembles our faith ir various gods trought history.Please, make a sequel, ASAP

Posted: July 22, 2013
												Words cannot express the deep and thoughtful world that Primordia is. Unless for some reason, you hate – and I mean, truly, with burning fire, HATE – point and click adventure games, you owe it to yourself to play this game.As dark as the world can seem, humor abounds in this game. The simple graphics are still beautifully rendered, and the characters you meet are ones who will climb inside your head, and stay for the long haul. With a cast of incredibly well realized and acted robots, the world doesn't just invite you in; it sucks you down, and makes you a part of it. Things in this game will be thought about days, weeks later. Enough cannot be said for how immersive this game is.As unfortunate and bleak as the world of Primordia may seem, it has many things I wish to see again. Perhaps, if enough people play Primordia, some day we can all go back together.

Posted: December 25, 2012
												The flaws:  It's very short, lasting around 6 hours if you don't linger too much on the puzzles, which are sometimes (later on in the game) reliant on numbers and math to an extent that there was no way I wouldn't be pulling out a guide.  Worse, when I found the numbers needed to solve a puzzle, I wondered how the writers even arrived at that solution.  Evidently, I cannot math.  (Thankfully, though, plenty of other puzzles are subtle yet logical, and a pleasure to work out.)  Some of the dialogue here is pretty cornball, clashing with the dreary dystopian setting, but then again I suppose that fits with the tradition of this style of game.  Beyond these issues, Primordia enjoys an aesthetic drawing from Giger, Moebius, Dune, and probably a bit of Machinarium and/or Beneath a Steel Sky, with music that recalls Blade Runner and Kaiba.  The scope of the story and its setting suggests far more than the ground you actually cover, but just that it seems so sprawling is wonderful.  Primordia feels like a labor of love.

Posted: December 20, 2013
												I bought this game out of blue, just from curiosity and nostalgy for the old games. So I expected absolutely nothing from it... And had found a beautiful jewel, proudly shining through the pixels of sepia-colored design. I don't want to talk about the plot - you should walk through the whole story by yourself, to feel & understand the world and its inhabitants, to see the whole story from your point of view and to decide, what will happen at the end. I will just say that if you're looking for a game with not-so-simple story, with ability to choose how to solve difficult situation, with an almost alive (figuratively, of course) characters - this game is what you are looking for.P.S. If you're scared off by the drawing style - believe me, I's bringing absolutely unique feelings about this game. It's totally charming and I couldn't imagine this game any other way.

Posted: November 10, 2013
												With gorgeously rendered pixel art, tight voice acting and dialogue, and a story that starts fiendishly simple and mutates into something more in careful pace with the narrative, Primordia is a definite must-play that touches on posthumanism, identity, religion, old vs new, and so much more. With a ridiculously number of possible endings and engaging puzzles in true point-and-click adventure 'what the hell kind of combo was that' style, it's a short but involving experience.

Posted: December 16, 2012
												As a person who has never played a single adventure game before in his life, Primordia caught my eye with its visuals and premise. From its art style, well done puzzles, top-notch voice acting, and great story, its an amazing little gem that you should not pass up. The challenges are usually rough, sometimes easy, but are always rewarding. The writing itself is enough to keep you going; witty, and like everything else, masterfully done. Posted: May 26, 2013
												One of the better adventure games I've played. The puzzles generally make sense, the story's interesting enough to keep your attention and it's got Abe Goldfarb in it. A few gripes: There are some bits where it's not clear that you can travel further to the side of particular scenes (which stumped me for a while), and there are some items you need to pick up that are pretty hard to see, but the worst is that there are some things you can fail to do (or do incorrectly) that will lock you out of some of the content. But those are pretty minor. Even if you do miss the optional bits, you still get most of it and it's impossible to get stuck in an unwinnable state. This is definitely an example of how adventure games should be.

Posted: March 12, 2014
												Unlike a lot of other adventure games, the puzzles in this one are literal logic puzzles. You play as a robot named Horatio who lives a hermit-ish existance in a post-human world with his little buddy Crispin. All is grand till a mean robot busts up your place and steals your home power supply. So now it's a quest of revenge and such. Great little game. No major issues bug-wise since they've been patched out as far as I can see. I believe it's a total of 6 endings or so. It's not completely linear but there are parts that have to be completed in certain ways if you want the achievements. Late-ish in the game there is an achievement everyone hates that requires you to enter all key words into the kiosk. If you don't have the monocle, don't worry about it yet. I recommend 2 videos on youtube by Tomoch. Write the words he uses down then type them in, don't save half way through. Do exactly what he does. Click the mores on the screen, don't type more. If you do both of those videos by the letter you should get the achievement which many people still cannot get. Achievements aside, this is a golden adventure point & click game with challenging logic puzzles with a dash of humour.

Set in a dystopian world where all humans have died years ago, you play as a robot and his sidekick trying to recover a stolen power core. The puzzles are pretty intuitive and not too frustrating (like many adventure games are for me). It's very cyberpunkish  with retro 16-bit graphics. It's also very reminicent of Beneath a Steel Sky, one of my favorite adventure games which is now freeware.

Posted: July 23, 2013
												I think this game is awesome; a really well made Indie Adventure title. Reminiscent of 90's PC adventure games, Primordia is a 'point and click' game in which you must use skills of logical deduction, puzzle solving, listening and recall to complete all tasks and find all usable objects. I really like the tone created by the graphics, artwork/scenery, soundtrack and dialogue; I quite liked Horatio and Crispin as protagonists, too. The game has backstory that ties into the plot nicely, and I didn't find it overly expansive or tedious. The world in the game is quite small, but its an appropriate fit for the length of the story and the style of gameplay. I highly recommend this, its a beautiful little game. *****

												Primordia is a well done point and click adventure game, but those new to the genre may find it frustrating and inconsistent. Point and click adventure games depend on their characters and setting, and Primordia delivers in both. The NPC robots who inhabit the world are all distinctive and have personality, but the real centrepieces are the two main characters. Horatio, the playable protagonist, plays the straight man to Crispin, his robot sidekick who I personally found kind of annoying. However, Crispin's sarcasm and jokes do a lot to lighten the mood established by the setting. Primordia takes place in a post-apocalyptic world inhabited entirely by robots. As a crucial and interesting element of this world, some of the robots worship humanity, who they view as their creators and the originators of the world. The world itself is interesting to look at and there are some really striking setpieces in several of the stages. I won't really discuss the story, but I will say that the "good" ending resolves much more than any of the other ones. Though you have to be careful as there are a couple decisions in the game that can lock you out of getting what seems to be the only ending that gives you some sense of closure. The graphics are done in a retro, psuedo-16 bit style that can occasionally make it difficult to determine which objects are in the background and which are interactive objects. Furthermore, my biggest problem with the game comes when you try to use these objects. Several times in the game you have to use Crispin to retrieve objects that are out of reach but the things he can do and the types of objects he can get aren't consistent. Sometimes he can bump things off ledges but other times he can't, sometimes he can use a keypad and other times he can't, sometimes he can fly into a pipe and get something and other times he can't. What it boils down to is trying everything you can and relying on trial and error to solve several puzzles as things that worked last time don't now for mainly arbitrary reasons.Overall, Primordia is an interesting, well-fleshed out point and click adventure game that occasionally doesn't follow it's own rules. But if you can get past hearing "I don't think that will work" several dozen times you'll find a fascinating world filled with a host of unique characters.

Posted: July 23, 2013
												I think this game is awesome; a really well made Indie Adventure title. Reminiscent of 90's PC adventure games, Primordia is a 'point and click' game in which you must use skills of logical deduction, puzzle solving, listening and recall to complete all tasks and find all usable objects. I really like the tone created by the graphics, artwork/scenery, soundtrack and dialogue; I quite liked Horatio and Crispin as protagonists, too. The game has backstory that ties into the plot nicely, and I didn't find it overly expansive or tedious. The world in the game is quite small, but its an appropriate fit for the length of the story and the style of gameplay. I highly recommend this, its a beautiful little game. *****

Posted: July 22, 2013
												Words cannot express the deep and thoughtful world that Primordia is. Unless for some reason, you hate – and I mean, truly, with burning fire, HATE – point and click adventure games, you owe it to yourself to play this game.As dark as the world can seem, humor abounds in this game. The simple graphics are still beautifully rendered, and the characters you meet are ones who will climb inside your head, and stay for the long haul. With a cast of incredibly well realized and acted robots, the world doesn't just invite you in; it sucks you down, and makes you a part of it. Things in this game will be thought about days, weeks later. Enough cannot be said for how immersive this game is.As unfortunate and bleak as the world of Primordia may seem, it has many things I wish to see again. Perhaps, if enough people play Primordia, some day we can all go back together.

												Fun little puzzle solver. Short (I finished my first run through in about 6 hours) but with a lovely little story. Most of the puzzles are solvable with a little thought, although from the look of the achievements I haven't unlocked, there are a few puzzles I either missed or got locked out of by my story choices.I'm not sure what the full price was, but if and when this shows up as flash sale, its very worth a $3-4 sale price.

Posted: December 9, 2012
												There was an era of adventure gaming that I really loved: the 90s LucasArts-style era.  These were games that ran in 256-color MCGA mode and had MIDI soundtracks.  If you were fortunate enough to own, rather than download, these games, you might even have gotten the voice tracks.This game is a lot like those.  It has some puzzles that make little sense and some arbitrary hurdles, but on the whole, it holds up very well.  The surplus of endings is interesting, as well.  Primordia doesn't have a very long playthrough, which is nice.  It's like a novella and it just hits the spot.

Posted: November 5, 2013
												I haven't been this happy since Grim Fandango. It's a 16-bit point-and-click adventure (in the play style of Curse of Monkey Island) in sepia tones. The game is fully voice acted, and it's the least annoying voice acting ever. The lead is voiced by Logan Cunningham, the guy who narrated Bastion, and the other characters and voices thus far have been FANTASTIC. At one point, I had to set the mouse aside to get pencil and paper out because a pair of indignant robots wanted me to settle a legal dispute, but not until after proving my worthiness by solving a logical story problem. Basically I have spent six times as much money on games that were one tenth as engaging and wonderful. I don't know why this game isn't blowing up my friends list already, but hey, now you know.

Posted: March 13, 2013
												Сколько видов историй о машинах вы знаете?Небось только о том, что "МАШИНЫ УНИЧТОЖАЮТ ЧЕЛОВЕЧЕСТВО, ДАДИМ ИМ ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ЮЛЕЙ И СПСЁМ ЦИВИЛИЗАЦИЮ".А вы когда-нибудь видели, что бы машины ПОКЛОНЯЛИСЬ человеку?Человеку, которого никто не видел уже давно.Что бы человек для них был богом?Что бы был религией?Horatio Nullbuilt, version 5 - он верит в человека, он полностью изучил Gospel of Man.Он довольно таки необычный робот.У него есть друг, которого он же и построил - Crispin Horatiobuilt, version one.В двоём они живут в постапокалиптичном мире на корабле UNNIC, застрявшем в пустоше и который обеспечен энергией благодаря Power Core.Всё было тихо и спокойно.Пока не пришёл большой робот с лазером, не подстрелил Horatio и утащил Power Core.Остался лишь резервный генератор, которого надолго не хватит.Пора отправляться на поиски...-----------------Такова сюжетная завязка игры Primordia.Primordia - великолепный пиксельный квест, сделанный знатоками таковых из студии Wadjet Eye Games.Эти ребята создали такие прекрасные вещи, как The Blackwell Series, Resonance и Geminy Rue.О дааа, эти ребята знают в квестах толк.Я люблю все квесты их студии - они того заслуживают.И Primordia я люблю больше всех.Почему?Сейчас поясню.------------------Дамы и господа, взгляните пожалуйста на сюжет.Он прекрасен.Превосходен.Да, завязка проста, но вот дальнейшее...Сюжет очень проработан и глубок, мрачен и безысходен.Он бесподобен.И это - важно.Ведь это квест, в квесте главное - сюжет и головоломки.Кстати о таковых.Ну, решать местные задачки не так уж ипросто.Порой сломать голову просто.Потому что не додумаешься до очевидного.И это - хорошо.Хоть и бесит порой, но хорошо.Да и пиксельхантинга тут мало - это тоже хорошо.Вообщем, замечательно.Но куда замечательнее атмосфера.Атмосфера, состоящее из двух превосходных факторов - графона и звука.Графон - превосходный пиксельный рай. Всё настолько хорошо прорисованно, настолько красиво, мрачно, детально, что мои глаза просто получают удовольствие от увиденного.Этот прекрасный постапокалиптичный мир...Пустоши, груды желеезного ржавого мусора.Безысходность...А звук здесь ахренителен.Эмбиэнт, музыка, звуки окружения - всё на высшем уровне.В особенности я хочу сказать это про озвучку.Она бесподобна.
